video:video.video:description: Robot museum guides, bitcoin ATMS, and levitation trains – no this isn’t a sci-fi movie, its a travel guide. In this episode of Good As Gold, we give tech-lovers the thing they’ve been missing: tech-centric travel recommendations. Get a closer look at two of the most advanced cities in the world with the help of travel pros Claire Marshall and Peter Bragiel.

video:video.video:title: The Fascinating Math Behind Why You Won't Win The Powerball
video:video.video:description: The Powerball jackpot is over a billion dollars but what are your chances?

video:video.video:title: SB 100 - How Tracking Technology Is Changing Football
video:video.video:description: RFID tags embedded in uniforms will give football teams, players and fans unprecedented deep data to measure athletic performance, even in live games.

video:video.video:title: New Social App Peach Lets You Throw Cake
video:video.video:description: The new social mobile app Peach is like a mashup of Twitter and a Slack group chat with some nice integration to other features on your phone like fitness, weather and music. Also, it lets you throw cake at friends.

video:video.video:title: Chevrolet's Bolt is the People's Electric Car
video:video.video:description: Chevrolet just won the race to produce a truly affordable electric vehicle with triple-digit range. WIRED transportation editor Alex Davies takes the new car for spin at CES 2016.

video:video.video:title: CES 2016 - WIRED's Top Gadget Trends from CES
video:video.video:description: Drones, throwback gadgets and the ever growing world of connected Internet of Things gear topped WIRED's CES 2016 trends.

video:video.video:title: CES 2016 - WIRED's Favorite Gadgets of CES
video:video.video:description: CES is a seemingly endless bonanza of product debuts. Everything from cars and drones to headphones and televisions is on display and in mind-boggling quantities. These products are WIRED's favorites.

video:video.video:title: CES 2016 - Autonomous Drone That Seats One Is a Special Kind of Crazy
video:video.video:description: Perhaps the most audacious product on display at CES 2016 is Ehang's concept autonomous single-occupancy drone, the 184. The $200,000 to $300,000 helicopter will offer rides up to 23 minutes at the push of a smartphone app button.

video:video.video:title: CES 2016 - Polaroid's New Super-Cute, Super-Affordable Printing Camera
video:video.video:description: Print those selfies immediately! Polaroid's Snap camera is perfect for any party and it costs less than $100.

video:video.video:title: CES 2016 - Four Gadgets That Could Make Life More Convenient
video:video.video:description: WIRED executive editor Joe Brown checks out a temperature regulating coffee cup, a connected flowerpot, a remote pet food dispenser and a very loud speaker that doubles as a beverage cooler.

video:video.video:title: CES 2016 - 8K TVs Are Coming to Market, and Your Eyeballs Aren’t Ready
video:video.video:description: 4K is so 2015. This year LG will begin selling an 8K television. We don't know what it will cost yet or what you might be able to play on it, but it's pretty cool.

video:video.video:title: CES 2016 - Fridges for the Future
video:video.video:description: LG's Signature Fridge and Samsung's Family Hub Refrigerator concepts are a glimpse of the future of connected, touchscreen and app-controlled refrigerators that might even order their own groceries.

video:video.video:title: SB 100: How Virtual Reality Works as a Training Tool
video:video.video:description: Andrew Wasserman from Strivr explains how virtual reality helps top athletes get better, and how the technology is getting more and more realistic.

video:video.video:title: SB 100 - SB100 - Who Will Play Football in the Future?
video:video.video:description: Professional football may face a shortage of talented players as researchers understand more about head injuries and parents and young players follow recommendations for reducing risk.

video:video.video:title: SB 100 - SB100 - How New Rules and Technology Could Change Football
video:video.video:description: Come time for Super Bowl 100 in the year 2066, football will likely bear little resemblance to the sport we now know.

video:video.video:title: SB 100 - SB100 | Inside the NFL’s Quest to Build a Truly Global League
video:video.video:description: the NFL made no secret of its desire to bring American football to a new international stage.

video:video.video:title: The Clothing of the Future Could Shift Shape With Just a Glance
video:video.video:description: Designer Behnaz Farahi's 3-D printed vest can say "back off" without ever uttering a word thanks to eye-tracking controlled movement.

video:video.video:title: SB 100 - SB100 | VR Will Soon Revolutionize How Football Players Train
video:video.video:description: From inside the Oculus Rift headset, players get a 3-D look at the field while headphones provide realistic sound. Teams capture the footage by filming their practices with 360-degree cameras, so the experience inside the VR headset looks and sounds like the real thing rather than a video game.

video:video.video:title: Wired's Top Five Transportation Stories
video:video.video:description: Getting from A to B has never been more exciting than it was in 2015. We've got the best transportation stories of the year for you.

video:video.video:title: Practical Design Dominates 2015
video:video.video:description: For companies and consumers, 2015 was a big year for practical design. Wired tells you why.

video:video.video:title: Fantastic Negrito Sings "Lost in a Crowd" At WIRED
video:video.video:description: Musician Fantastic Negrito plays his song "Lost in a Crowd" at WIRED's San Francisco office.

video:video.video:title: Wired's Top Five Science Stories of 2015
video:video.video:description: It was a good year for finding stuff out and our favorite science stories all revealed something about the universe.

video:video.video:title: Wired's Top Five Security Stories Of 2015
video:video.video:description: 2015 showed that the Internet is a dangerous place. Whether it’s your cellular-connected car or personal details on an adulterous dating website, no one seems safe anymore.

video:video.video:title: The Dark Side of Christmas, Explained with Holiday Cookies
video:video.video:description: It's not all twinkly lights, wrapped presents, and Yule logs. Uncover the darker side of Christmas from the 83 million trees that get chopped down to the $616.9 billion spent in November and December.

video:video.video:title: Surviving Your Trip Without Data | Good As Gold Presented By American Express
video:video.video:description: No foreign data while traveling abroad? No problem. From navigating map apps in offline mode, to saving digital copies of your important travel documents, this episode of Good As Gold has you covered. Use these tips from travel vlogger Peter Bragiel (pdrop) to survive abroad when your data doesn’t follow you.

video:video.video:title: Wired's Top Five Gadgets Of 2015
video:video.video:description: It's been a good year for gear heads, so we've put together our top 5 gadgets of 2015.

video:video.video:title: Wired's Top Five Entertainment Stories Of 2015
video:video.video:description: Music wars, television scandals, movie masterpieces and major disappointments, 2015 had it all. Have a look at our biggest entertainment stories from the last year.

video:video.video:title: Absurd Creatures | This Fish Makes Hawaii's Beaches in an ... Interesting Way
video:video.video:description: Love white sand beaches? Thank the bizarre parrotfish which eats coral and poops out sand. Oh, it also sleeps in a pile of snot.

video:video.video:title: You'll Never Believe How We Got You to Click on This Video
video:video.video:description: Clickbait isn't art, it's a science. Click and find out how it works.

video:video.video:title: Darth Vader Force-Chokes Star Wars Fans in Line for The Force Awakens
video:video.video:description: Outside the TCL Chinese Theatre in Hollywood unsuspecting fans find out what it’s like to get force-choked by Darth Vader.

video:video.video:title: Meet the Star Wars Fans Who Lined Up Two Weeks Before the Premiere
video:video.video:description: We caught up with fans who lined up for tickets nearly two weeks before the release of Star Wars: The Force Awakens. From keeping your job to keeping your marriage, the cosplay-dressing superfans break down the rules to waiting in line.

video:video.video:title: SB 100: The Media Will Have a Very Different Role at Super Bowl 100
video:video.video:description: With changes in technology, the popularity of the game, and how fans interact with players, our media panel sees big changes ahead in Super Bowl coverage.

video:video.video:title: SB 100: How to Watch the Super Bowl in Space
video:video.video:description: Astronauts who have flown aboard the International Space Station discuss how and why it's important for them to watch football and other sports in orbit.

video:video.video:title: Data Attack - Everything You Didn't Know About Star Wars, Explained with Action Figures
video:video.video:description: What's Darth Vader's death count? How many Lego sets has the franchise sold? Which nation accepts Star Wars collectable coins as real currency? Find out everything you didn’t know about the epic franchise, as told by Star Wars action figures.

video:video.video:title: Star Wars: The Force Awakens | WIRED Movie Review
video:video.video:description: If you loved Star Wars once, everything you loved is back. And if you’re new? Welcome home.

video:video.video:title: Want To Make Artisanal Ice At Home? Here's How
video:video.video:description: Forget going the bar for beautiful, crystal clear ice. You can now make artisanal ice cubes at home with the $80 Studio Neat Ice Kit. A perfect gift for any aspiring mixologist.

video:video.video:title: Coravin's Wine Gadget Lets You Drink One Glass Now, Save the Rest
video:video.video:description: The $330 Coravin Wine System beats a corkscrew any day and makes sipping and saving wine easy. It slides thorough the cork and fills the bottle with an inert gas as you pour, so leftover wine won't spoil.

video:video.video:title: How to Build a Death Star According to a NASA Engineer
video:video.video:description: NASA’s Brian Muirhead explains how to build a Death Star and tells us what it would really be like to fly past a flurry of asteroids.

video:video.video:title: SB 100 - Super Bowl 100: Inside the Burke Institute
video:video.video:description: The Burke Institute in White Plains, NY is using innovative techniques to more accurately diagnose brain trauma, and hopefully better understand and prevent degenerative brain conditions like CTE.

video:video.video:title: SB 100 - Super Bowl 100: How the NFL Can Survive the Concussion Epidemic
video:video.video:description: As the NFL begins to address the existential problems that brain trauma pose, see how innovations in protection, impact monitoring, and training techniques are being developed to protect players.

video:video.video:title: You Can Actually Duel With These Awesome Custom Lightsabers
video:video.video:description: As Star Wars fans have grown up, so have their lightsabers. Forget cheap plastic toys, these sabers are bespoke laser blades that light up, buzz, and are made for Jedi dueling.

video:video.video:title: How ADHD Became a Multi-Billion Dollar Industry
video:video.video:description: The rise of ADHD diagnoses over the years has generated $13 billion in revenue for the companies that produce ADHD medication in the United States. Find out how the increase in attention deficit hyperactivity disorders is resulting in a big payday for big pharma.

video:video.video:title: Gear Review: Google Pixel C
video:video.video:description: The Pixel C shows Google has a lot of work left to do to compete with a growing class of multitasking work tablets says WIRED's David Pierce.

video:video.video:title: NASA Would Take C-3P0 to Space But Not R2-D2 or BB-8
video:video.video:description: Brett Kennedy, a roboticist at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Lab, breaks down the plausibility (or lack thereof) of Star Wars characters like R2-D2, C-3PO and the new BB-8.

video:video.video:title: This Guy Can Teach You How to Memorize Anything
video:video.video:description: Joshua Foer can remember anything, including the first 100 digits of Pi. The former U.S.A. Memory Champion explains how he—and you—can memorize anything using the major system technique, which converts numbers into words and images.

video:video.video:title: Making Sense of All the New Force Awakens Footage
video:video.video:description: It might seem like we've been watching the same Star Wars: The Force Awakens clips for months, but new clues emerge each time a new trailer, clip or teaser is released.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - How “The Good Dinosaur” Raised the Bar for Natural-World CGI
video:video.video:description: Find out how Pixar raised the CGI bar for ultra-realistic environments and landscapes in “The Good Dinosaur.”

video:video.video:title: YouTube Star MKBHD Reviews the Best Holiday Gifts for Your Favorite Techie
video:video.video:description: Not sure what to get your tech-head friends for the holidays? YouTube star MKBHD reviews the Fitbit ChargeHR, Verizon’s Droid Turbo 2, and the Bose SoundLink mini speaker so you can get the right gadget for the right guy or gal.

video:video.video:title: Testing Out the Star Wars BB-8 Toy & More Gadget Gifts with YouTuber MKBHD
video:video.video:description: From the Samsung Gear S2 smartwatch to the Star Wars Sphero BB-8 toy, Youtuber MKBHD gives a few gadgets a spin to help you figure out what to put on your wish list this holiday season.

video:video.video:title: 9 MIT Media Lab Innovations that Changed the Future
video:video.video:description: From touchscreens to E ink and GPS to Guitar Hero, some of today’s most popular technologies all originated from the same place: the MIT Media Lab. To celebrate its 30th anniversary current and former directors count down the nine most influential innovations to come out of the future-forward lab.

video:video.video:title: Think Like a Tree - How a Dog Inspired Velcro and a Bat Inspired Radar
video:video.video:description: How can we move toward a more sustainable world? By looking to nature where many of our problems have already been solved. Find out how inventors and scientists developed things like velcro and radar by looking at—and imitating—dogs and bats.

video:video.video:title: The Commercial Space Race Heats Up
video:video.video:description: The private American companies battling it out for a $3.5 billion NASA contract have one last chance to successfully launch their spacecraft before a decision is made in January.

video:video.video:title: Illuminating Extinction: Projecting a Snow Leopard on the Empire State Building
video:video.video:description: Massive images of the worlds endangered species were projected onto the Empire State Building to call attention to the upcoming release of Discovery's documentary, Racing Extinction.

video:video.video:title: Think Like a Tree - Did You Know the Eiffel Tower Was Inspired by Your Femur?
video:video.video:description: Find out how human bones inspired the Eiffel Tower through the design principle of structural hierarchy.

video:video.video:title: I Went to the Drone World Expo and Saw the Future. It Sounds Like Bees
video:video.video:description: This is the first annual Drone World Expo, 75 exhibitors and over 2,000 drone pros in the San Jose Convention Center in the heart of Silicon Valley.

video:video.video:title: Think Like a Tree - How Moth Eyes Inspired the Camera Lens
video:video.video:description: Find out how camera lenses take after moths by mimicking the way they absorb and hold in light.

video:video.video:title: Lighting Up the World With a One-of-a-Kind Tesla Model S
video:video.video:description: In order to cast a light on a global issue like climate change, the team behind the new film Racing Extinction turned a standard Tesla Model S into a “mobile projection vehicle.” See what mods they made, and follow along at www.facebook.com/racingextinction

video:video.video:title: The Ultimate Star Wars Lego Destruction Mashup
video:video.video:description: An epic mash-up of all our crazy Star Wars Lego Destruction videos!

video:video.video:title: WIRED – December 2015 – The Force Will Be With Us. Always.
video:video.video:description: Travelling through hyperspace ain’t like dusting crops. Neither is making movies. In preparation for Star Wars: Episode VII, WIRED’s Editor in Chief Scott Dadich sat down with J.J. Abrams to discuss his trajectory from awestruck super fan to the director of The Force Awakens. Also this month: Transforming the Pentagon with Silicon Valley, how India’s decision on energy can affect the entire planet, the amazing products to give and get this holiday season, plus more.

video:video.video:title: Gift Guide | Headphones for Everyone
video:video.video:description: Do you or love music? Does someone on your gift list? Then you probably need some nice headphones. Here's how to pick the right pair and fit them for the best sound.

video:video.video:title: Think Like a Tree - How Sea Organisms Are Changing the Way We Make Glue
video:video.video:description: Your new kitchen cabinets might contain a glue in them that was inspired by mussels. Explore the chemistry that mussels use when attaching to boats and find out how that science is being imitated to develop strong adhesives that don’t rely on toxic formaldehyde.

video:video.video:title: Star Wars Lego Destruction - Star Wars Lego Death Star Gets Destroyed with a Baseball Bat
video:video.video:description: It took 3,449 pieces to put together this Star Wars Lego Death Star. Watch it get destroyed in seconds with a baseball bat!

video:video.video:title: Think Like a Tree - What Can a Humpback Whale Teach a Wind Turbine?
video:video.video:description: One’s in the water and one’s in the air, but they share one thing in common: both are trying to reduce drag along their surfaces. Find out why scientists are studying humpback whales as they look to create more efficient wind turbines.

video:video.video:title: Star Wars Lego Destruction - Behind the Scenes: Star Wars Lego Death Star Gets Destroyed with a Baseball Bat
video:video.video:description: It was already partially assembled, but it still took more than three hours to put together this Star Wars Lego Death Star. See how it all came together.

video:video.video:title: SB 100 - How a 2,000-Year-Old Arena Could Hold the Key to Future Stadium Design
video:video.video:description: Dan Meis explains the challenges of building an iconic building in the back yard of Rome's Colosseum, and how the enduring life of the classic arena should provide a lesson for the future of stadium design.

video:video.video:title: SB 100 - SB100: Check Out a Reimagined NFL Stadium for the Future
video:video.video:description: In the future, NFL teams won't play in sterile concrete bowls. Instead, they will play in multi-use spaces near the urban core, redefining our idea of what a stadium is.

video:video.video:title: Cove Puts You In Touch With Your Emotions Through Music
video:video.video:description: It turns out emotions are complex (surprise!), and sometimes words just can’t do justice in expressing them. Cove, a new app, helps translate feelings into music.

video:video.video:title: App Pack | VR Apps For Google Cardboard
video:video.video:description: Google Cardboard and a smartphone are all you need to experience the immersive world of virtual reality. WIRED's Molly McHugh explores apps for news, gaming, and thrills.

video:video.video:title: Star Wars Lego Destruction - A Millennium Falcon Lego Replica Plummets Into Jakku
video:video.video:description: Watch all 1,329 Lego pieces of a replica Star Wars Millennium Falcon plunge into the desert planet Jakku.

video:video.video:title: What's Inside - What’s Inside a Flu Shot?
video:video.video:description: Each year the World Health Organization determines which of the thousands of influenza variants are most likely to circulate. Flu vaccines then use these variants at the starting point when developing the annual flu shot. Find out what’s inside the influenza-warding shot.

video:video.video:title: Inside the World of Drone Racing
video:video.video:description: It’s a new industry, but the world of drone racing is quickly becoming a popular sport. Watch to learn about the tech behind it and find out what the Drone Racing League is all about.

video:video.video:title: The Tech Behind a Racing Drone
video:video.video:description: The Drone Racing League is gearing up for a massive 2016 debut. Tim Moynihan explores the technology and design behind the racing drones.

video:video.video:title: Think Like a Tree - What Termites Can Teach Architects About Skyscraper Design
video:video.video:description: Sure, they’re pesky critters but termites can teach architects a thing or two when it comes building design. When creating giant mounds the insects build channels within them to help with ventilation. See how architects are attempting to replicate that process to create better heating and air conditioning systems in giant skyscrapers.

video:video.video:title: Toyota’s Funky i-Road Is Like Nothing I’ve Ever Driven
video:video.video:description: The i-Road's a new kind of three-wheeled concept that Toyota thinks we'll one day use to zip around city centers burning nothing but rubber.

video:video.video:title: Sea Lion Flippers Could Inspire Super-Stealthy Submersibles
video:video.video:description: Sea lions are incredible and unusual swimmers. One day engineers could use the sea lion’s secrets to create super-maneuverable, super-stealthy vehicles that’ll better navigate dangers like underwater minefields.

video:video.video:title: Star Wars Lego Destruction - Star Wars Lego X-Wing Fighter vs. Death Star
video:video.video:description: Watch a flaming LEGO X-Wing smash into the Death Star as we re-create the Rebels’ fatal attack.

video:video.video:title: Star Wars Lego Destruction - Behind the Scenes: Star Wars Lego X-Wing Fighter vs. Death Star
video:video.video:description: It took two crashes and 1,559 Lego pieces to re-create the X-Wing fighter facing off against the Death Star. See how we pulled it off.

video:video.video:title: Gear Review | WIRED's Creative Team Tests Apple's iPad Pro and Pencil
video:video.video:description: Apple's new iPad Pro is designed for professional creative work, so we put it to the test. A WIRED photographer, designer and video producer tried using the tablet and Apple's new Pencil stylus to retouch images, draw and edit video.

video:video.video:title: Gear Review | Apple iPad Pro
video:video.video:description: This tablet does things your phone and your laptop can't do. Are they solutions in search of a problem? Perhaps. But the iPad Pro is the best tablet, and the best case for tablets, anyone's ever made says WIRED's David Pierce.

video:video.video:title: Gear Review | Apple Pencil
video:video.video:description: Apple's new $99 Pencil stylus changes the tablet drawing game. It really is like you're putting ink on paper, says WIRED's David Pierce. It does a better job than almost any other stylus, ever, at sensing and responding to pressure, or angle.

video:video.video:title: Star Wars Lego Destruction - Star Wars Lego TIE Starfighter Gets Smashed by Asteroids
video:video.video:description: In Star Wars Episode III the TIE starfighter suffered a devastating blow from asteroid impact. Watch a slo-mo Lego replica of the crushing scene.

video:video.video:title: Instagram and VSCO Go Head to Head With New Gif Apps
video:video.video:description: Both Instagram and VSCO have new GIF apps out---so which one deserves your download? We tested them by recording lightsabers, drones, and cute dogs, of course!

video:video.video:title: Disney Infinity Star Wars: Taking Down AT-ATs
video:video.video:description: Procedural animation is used to create unique AT-AT takedowns every time you wrap your tow cable around one of the Empire's giant walkers in Disney Infinity.

video:video.video:title: Gear Review: Pebble Time Round
video:video.video:description: A few days after I started wearing the Time Round, Pebble's ultra-thin new smartwatch, I shut off notifications. This was partly practical---I get too many notifications, and the iPhone offers no filtering control over them---but also a thought experiment. Right now most people see a smartwatch as nothing more than a notification machine, a slightly faster way to see what that buzz in my pocket was all about. What if we took that away? What else could it be?

video:video.video:title: Beating Up James Bond is No Easy Task
video:video.video:description: “We beat the hell out of each other for weeks.” James Bond stars, Dave Bautista and 007 himself, Daniel Craig, explain how they ended up with a fractured nose and an emergency knee surgery by not holding back during the fight sequences in the new “Spectre” film.

video:video.video:title: Star Wars Lego Destruction - Star Wars Lego AT-AT Takes an Epic Fall at Hoth
video:video.video:description: It took three hours to build the 1,137-piece AT-AT Lego replica—watch the Rebels take it down in 0.12 seconds in an epic fall on icy Hoth.

video:video.video:title: Spectre | WIRED Movie Review
video:video.video:description: Is James Bond obsolete? The Joint Intelligence Service thinks spies, even super spies, are dinosaurs in an age of drones and wiretapping. But there's a more philosophical question: Are we over James Bond?

video:video.video:title: Cyborg Nation - Can Prosthetics Outperform Real Limbs?
video:video.video:description: MIT Media Lab's Hugh Herr explains how he looks to nature when developing new bionic appendages. The amputee and avid rock climber discusses how his biomechatronics division is pioneering the technologies that aim to augment human physical capabilities.

video:video.video:title: Cyborg Nation - This Technology Wants to Make Wheelchairs Obsolete
video:video.video:description: Ekso Bionics has a simple premise: create robotics that help people. And the company is doing just that with its wearable exoskeleton. Using a combination of weight-activated sensors and battery-powered motors, the bionic suit is helping wheelchair-bound users learn how to walk again.

video:video.video:title: Cyborg Nation - How to Control Things Using Your Brain (and Open-Source Hardware)
video:video.video:description: OpenBCI is an open-source hardware that allows a D.I.Y. community of artists, designers, and engineers to innovate, while serving as a tool for research and innovation. From using brain activity to control a toy spider to engaging a group in collective mind control, the open-source brain computer interface aims to change the way people interact with machines.

video:video.video:title: Cyborg Nation - This Robotic Hand Can Touch and Feel, Just Like a Human Hand
video:video.video:description: Imagine robotic fingers that can feel vibrations, textures, and temperatures. For those with prosthetic hands, it’s no longer a dream, it’s reality. Find out how one company is disrupting the prosthetic hand field by mimicking the sensation a hand feels with synthetic fingernails and fingerprints.

video:video.video:title: Cyborg Nation - Mind-Controlled Machines Give Paralyzed Patients New Hope
video:video.video:description: Brazilian scientist Dr. Miguel Nicolelis is leading the frontier on mind-controlled exoskeletons that can translate thoughts into physical movement. Go inside his lab and find out how he’s helping paraplegics control aid-enabling devices just by thinking.

video:video.video:title: Cyborg Nation - Cyborg Cockroaches Could Save Your Life
video:video.video:description: Most consider them pesky critters, but Dr. Alper Bozkurt of North Carolina State University thinks that cockroaches have the potential to save human lives. By hacking their antennae and transforming them into remote-controlled creatures, he believes we can use the cyber roaches as a mobile search and rescue team to help find survivors during natural disasters.

video:video.video:title: Watch the Sun Erupt in a Symphony of Solar Storms
video:video.video:description: NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory satellite uses specialized ultraviolet cameras to capture stunning images of the sun's solar storms.

video:video.video:title: The Jellyfish’s Swimming Secret? It’s a Master of Suction
video:video.video:description: New fluid dynamics research shows that jellyfish and lampreys essentially suction their way through Earth’s oceans. Understanding the creatures' movements could someday lead to more efficient boat designs.

video:video.video:title: Star Wars Lego Destruction - Behind the Scenes: Star Wars Lego AT-ST Walker Gets Obliterated by Swinging Logs
video:video.video:description: It took 1,058 pieces of Lego and three hours of build time to create a replica of an Imperial AT-ST. Go behind the scenes to see how it all came together.

video:video.video:title: Star Wars Lego Destruction - Star Wars Lego AT-ST Walker Gets Obliterated by Swinging Logs
video:video.video:description: See the chicken walker get demolished in slow-motion as we bring the Ewok log smash to life, using thousands of Lego pieces.

video:video.video:title: A New List App Takes You Inside Celebrities'... Lists
video:video.video:description: Actor B.J. Novak has a new app for making lists of anything you want. But the real fun is in browsing the lists of celebrities like Lena Dunham, Mindy Kaling, and Snoop Dogg.

video:video.video:title: Meet the Superhero of Cosplay
video:video.video:description: Costume and prop-maker Shawn Thorsson shows us how he creates impressive life-size replicas of movie and comic-book characters.

video:video.video:title: Absurd Creatures | Bats Are Totally Awesome. Trust Me, I'm a Vampire
video:video.video:description: Bats are awesome. They're the only mammals that truly fly, they have echolocation and, scientists have recently discovered, tiny hairs that helps them fly by feel.

video:video.video:title: How to Survive a Zombie Apocalypse
video:video.video:description: Logan Miller and Joey Morgan from "Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse" show you how to hack together an arsenal of weapons to fend off the walking dead.

video:video.video:title: WIRED <3 Lower Manhattan
video:video.video:description: Lower Manhattan is the NYC 'hood you've heard of but haven't met. We're proud to be part of the Downtown Alliance.

video:video.video:title: SB 100 - The Future of the NFL Game Ball
video:video.video:description: A physics professor re-imagines the size and shape of an NFL football in an effort to optimize it for flight. It turns out a couple of small changes can add a whole lot of distance, but how would that change the way the game is played?

video:video.video:title: SB 100 - Inside the Wilson Football Factory
video:video.video:description: Take a look inside the factory in Ada, Ohio where every single NFL game ball is made by hand.

video:video.video:title: Cooking With Fire: Testing the Sansaire Searing Kit for Sous Vide
video:video.video:description: Sous vide machines can make tasty fare but the technique often leaves meat gray and unappetizing. WIRED's Adam Rogers fires up the $159 Sansaire Sear home blowtorch to add a little sizzle to a steak.

video:video.video:title: Is NYC Really the Greatest City in the World?
video:video.video:description: What do other cities have that NYC doesn't? Well, Europe's great food halls, Sydney's robust ferry system, and Moscow's elegant train stations for starters. New York city-based architects Vishaan Chakrabarti and Gregg Pasquarelli analyze how urban metropolis from around the world stack up against the city that never sleeps.

video:video.video:title: Two Architects Give NYC a Makeover
video:video.video:description: From Times Square to the Empire State Building, New York City is known for its cultural landmarks and iconic institutions, but it also has its fair share of eyesores. Two NYC-based architects re-imagine their perfect version of the Big Apple.

video:video.video:title: Star Wars The Force Awakens | What We Know Now
video:video.video:description: The world was treated to the newest Star Wars The Force Awakens trailer on Monday. WIRED senior editor Peter Rubin breaks down what we know and don't know about the new film.

video:video.video:title: Review: Google Nexus 6P
video:video.video:description: How good can an Android phone be? Really, really good.

video:video.video:title: Danny Boyle Reveals the Real Impact of Steve Jobs
video:video.video:description: "Steve Jobs" director Danny Boyle discusses how the Apple co-founder elevated the role of tech CEO to modern day storyteller. Boyle also explains his personal heroes in the technology world, from the founders of Wikipedia to Sir Tim Berners-Lee.

video:video.video:title: Absurd Creatures | Comb Jellies Are Ready to Rave
video:video.video:description: Put the comb jelly in the spotlight and watch it groove. The sea creatures turn into pulsating rainbows of movement under the right lighting, no disco ball needed.

video:video.video:title: The Last Witch Hunter | WIRED Movie Review
video:video.video:description: The Last Witch Hunter is a movie starring Vin Diesel where he, yes, hunts witches. That's all you really need to know. If watching the fast-car-driving voice of Groot go hard on some magic-makers sounds like your idea of a good time, Diesel is here to put a spell on you. If not, search for your enchantments elsewhere.

video:video.video:title: Take Back the Net
video:video.video:description: We asked a group of experts what Silicon Valley can do about online harassment.

video:video.video:title: Guillermo del Toro's Top 5 Horror Films
video:video.video:description: The "Crimson Peak" director lists his favorite scary movies of all time and talks about his own encounters with ghosts.

video:video.video:title: Talking Pictures | The Longest Night
video:video.video:description: Photographer Philip Montgomery narrates a selection of images from "The Longest Night" his project documenting protests in Ferguson, Missouri and the interaction between police and communities of color.

video:video.video:title: The Surface Book Really Is the Ultimate Laptop
video:video.video:description: WIRED's David Pierce reviews the Surface Book, Microsoft's kick-ass laptop that the company figured out how to turn into a convertible hybrid PC.

video:video.video:title: Microsoft's Surface Pro 4: A Hybrid on Its Way to Greatness
video:video.video:description: The laptop-tablet hybrid is clearly the future of Windows mobility, so it makes sense that Microsoft is trying to corner the market.

video:video.video:title: What It's Like to Pull 4 G's in a Stunt Jet
video:video.video:description: Hitching a ride with the pilots of the Breitling Jet Team made me feel like chewed gum being slowly, ruthlessly pulled apart. I want to do it again.

video:video.video:title: Inside the Making of the Apatosaurus from ‘Jurassic World’
video:video.video:description: In this behind-the-scenes video from the making of ‘Jurassic World,’ director Colin Trevorrow explains why he needed an animatronic dinosaur for one key scene.

video:video.video:title: Crimson Peak | WIRED Movie Review
video:video.video:description: Guillermo del Toro's new film isn't a horror show, it's a gothic romance but it isn't all that romantic. It does have wonderfully detailed ghosts, a haunted house, beautiful costumes and Jessica Chastain gets to let loose as an unhinged Victorian.

video:video.video:title: Yuneec Typhoon Q500 4K Aerial Footage
video:video.video:description: To test the image quality and picture stability of the Q500's 4K camera, we flew the drone around in Athens, Georgia.

video:video.video:title: Director Danny Boyle on Why “Steve Jobs” Is Not a Biopic
video:video.video:description: “Steve Jobs” is more than just a biopic. Director Danny Boyle explains the unique approach he took by shooting the movie in three different film formats to capture the life and achievements of the Apple co-founder.

video:video.video:title: App Uses Kids' Obsession With Phones to Teach Coding
video:video.video:description: Tiny Bop makes beautiful apps like Everything Machine which uses a smartphone's camera, gyroscope, light, speakers and microphone to teach coding through games.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Find Out How FX Experts Created Mars in "The Martian"
video:video.video:description: Visual effects companies Framestore and MPC were tasked with creating the red planet in “The Martian.” From realistic landscape shots of Mars to simulated gravity differences, see how it all came together with a shorter-than-usual timeframe for post-production.

video:video.video:title: Guillermo del Toro Explains Why “Crimson Peak” is Not a Horror Flick
video:video.video:description: Don’t call Guillermo del Toro’s new film “Crimson Peak” a horror film. The director explains why his new movie classifies as a gothic romance, and he talks about how they built a real version of the castle that’s featured in the flick.

video:video.video:title: Watch Battle Drones Cage Fight
video:video.video:description: No longer just for aerial photography and stunt aerobatics, hobbyists have found a new use for drones: making them fight.

video:video.video:title: The New iMac’s Biggest Changes? The Keyboard and Trackpad
video:video.video:description: Apple's new iMacs looks a lot like its past iMacs but with better screens and best of all, a Force Touch trackpad and a slimmer wireless keyboard.

video:video.video:title: This Beautiful App Is Like a Stress-Relieving Lava Lamp
video:video.video:description: Pause, a new $1.99 app isn't a typical game. There's no score and no competition. It's designed to help you zone out and relax by slowly chasing a beautiful blob of dots across your screen.

video:video.video:title: Ridley Scott's Top 5 Sci-Fi Films of All Time
video:video.video:description: "The Martian" director Ridley Scott counts down his favorite sci-fi films of all time.

video:video.video:title: These Adorable Owls Will Not Kill You With Plague
video:video.video:description: But they do have fleas! Researchers at Boise State University are trying to figure out how burrowing owls manage to host the plague-carrying fleas but don't get infected.

video:video.video:title: Steve Jobs | WIRED Movie Review
video:video.video:description: There have been a lot of movies made recently about the Apple founder. This is the one you should see.

video:video.video:title: Absurd Creatures | This Salamander Could Teach Humans How to Regrow Limbs
video:video.video:description: The axolotl is not only weirdly cute for an amphibian but it can also regenerate its own limbs. Scientists are studying how the salamanders regrow legs and how humans might someday do the same.

video:video.video:title: The Awesome but Buggy 360fly Cam Is for Early Adopters Only
video:video.video:description: The 360fly is a water-water-resistent virtual reality action sports camera that works with your phone and Google Cardboard. We tested the $400 camera at the California Academy of Sciences Steinhart Aquarium.

video:video.video:title: DNA Editing: Doping of the Future?
video:video.video:description: The ability to edit DNA is already here, but the effects of doing so are hardly understood. Genetics experts explain the potential pitfalls and alluring upside of using the technology on athletes.

video:video.video:title: The Elite Study: DNA of Extreme Human Performance
video:video.video:description: Dr. Euan Ashley and his team are gathering DNA samples from the most elite endurance athletes on the planet to find the genetic reasons that they are so fit.

video:video.video:title: Real Actors, Virtual Movies
video:video.video:description: The race to VR cinema has split into two tracks: either Pixar-like CGI that affords full immersion, or 360-degree video, which lacks true "presence." Uncorporeal's new technology is a marriage of the two, and gives us a glimpse at what the future of VR film could be.

video:video.video:title: SB 100 - How Science Is Hacking the Ultimate Athletes
video:video.video:description: Through motion tracking, data driven exercise, and eventually DNA analysis, SI and WIRED explore how scientific advances in training may help create the perfect NFL athlete.

video:video.video:title: Ridley Scott Explains What He’d Change in “The Martian” Based on NASA’s New Discovery
video:video.video:description: “The Martian” director Ridley Scott explains how NASA’s latest discovery on Mars would have affected the film’s plot and why he has zero interest in traveling to the far-off planet himself.

video:video.video:title: Fly Over Charon, Pluto's Biggest Moon
video:video.video:description: Skim the surface of Charon, Pluto's largest moon, in this stunning animation made up of images beamed back from NASA's space probe New Horizons.

video:video.video:title: Google Wants to Take the Wheel With Its Self-Driving Car
video:video.video:description: Google's self-driving car may look and sound like a giant Roomba but they may also be part of the future of automobile transportation.

video:video.video:title: Data Attack - Are You the Most Average Person in America?
video:video.video:description: Do you get 8.7 hours of sleep every night? Spend a daily total of 30 minutes in the bathroom? Use Facebook for 40 minutes (and Tinder for 77 minutes) each day? If so, you just might be the most average person in the U.S.

video:video.video:title: Absurd Creatures | This Caterpillar Freaks Out If You Yell At It
video:video.video:description: Caterpillars are sort of the Cheetos of the animal world. They're just waiting to become someone's snack. Some species have developed defense mechanisms. This caterpillar, found in Peru, has weird appendages it throws in the air when it senses dangerous sounds.

video:video.video:title: The Martian | WIRED Movie Review
video:video.video:description: The Martian, Ridley Scott's new space epic, takes audiences to the rugged surface of Mars. Matt Damon stars as left behind astronaut Mark Watney, who has to "science" his survival on the barren planet.

video:video.video:title: How to Make Your Facebook Profile Picture Into A Looping Video
video:video.video:description: Facebook has a new feature for some users that lets them turn their profile picture into a GIF-like video. WIRED's Dellea Chew demonstrates how she made a clip of her dog Dude into her Facebook looping video.

video:video.video:title: NASA Scientists Fact-Check “The Martian"
video:video.video:description: How accurate is the new space film “The Martian”? We had NASA scientists break down the science behind the movie to find out if Matt Damon’s portrayal of a stranded astronaut on Mars is realistic or out of this world.

video:video.video:title: Tesla Model X | First Look
video:video.video:description: Tesla's long awaited Model X SUV is finally here. The falcon-doored electric vehicle can carry seven passengers and is capable of rocketing to 60 miles per hour in as little as 3.2 seconds.

video:video.video:title: The Wove Band: Don't Call it a Smartwatch
video:video.video:description: The Wove Band by Polyera is the first wearable with a flexible touchscreen display. The devices won't be publicly available until 2016, but Polyera CEO Phil Inagaki gave us a behind the scenes look at some prototypes, and talked with us about his design philosophy.

video:video.video:title: NASA Discovers Evidence for Liquid Water on Mars
video:video.video:description: For years, scientists have known that Mars has ice. More elusive, though, is figuring out how much of that water is actually in liquid form. Now, NASA scientists have found compelling evidence that liquid water—life-giving, gloriously wet H 20—exists on Mars.

video:video.video:title: Flying in the Folding ICON A5 Airplane
video:video.video:description: For years we've been promised flying cars and for years we've been disappointed. The ICON A5, with its folding wings, may be the closest thing yet, and it's a boat, too! WIRED writer Tim Moynihan goes for a ride in the A5 over New York City.

video:video.video:title: Anki Overdrive is What You Always Wished Your Hot Wheels Could Be
video:video.video:description: Anki Overdrive combines the nostaligic toy race car fun of Hot Wheels with the smartphone control and artificial intelligence of Sphero. It's fun, really fun, but not without a few wrong turns.

video:video.video:title: Eli Roth Explains “The Green Inferno”—His New Cannibalistic Horror Film
video:video.video:description: Following Cabin Fever and Hostel, The Green Inferno is the latest film in Eli Roth’s travel trilogy. The director explains what inspired his new cannibalistic horror movie, and how he achieved a realistic look and feel while shooting on set in the Amazon.

video:video.video:title: Eli Roth’s Guide to Cannibalism
video:video.video:description: Eli Roth’s new horror film The Green Inferno delves into the world of cannibalism as only Roth can. Ahead of the new movie, the director breaks down his rules for engaging in cannibalism and shares the type of person he’d want to eat.

video:video.video:title: Get Ready for the Supermoon Eclipse
video:video.video:description: Polish up that telescope! This weekend night owls will enjoy the sight of a total lunar eclipse which will just happen to occur during a supermoon, when the moon passes closest to earth's surface.

video:video.video:title: Facebook Rolls Out 360 Video with Star Wars Clip
video:video.video:description: You’ll now be able to see immersive videos in your Facebook feed. As part of the rollout, you can speed across the Jakku desert of the upcoming Star Wars: The Force Awakens in a 360 video created by Disney exclusively for Facebook.

video:video.video:title: Absurd Creatures - Mantis Shrimp Fight Club
video:video.video:description: Mantis shrimp have a pair of hammer appendages that pack a powerful punch. They use them to smash prey open and fight each other for territory. Researchers at Duke University set up a mantis shrimp fight club to study their sparring behavior.

video:video.video:title: WIRED October Issue Preview - Cities by Design
video:video.video:description: Cities used to grow (more or less) by accident. Today cities develop more intentionally. From Shanghai to Nairobi, designers, architects, and planners are using better materials, smart science, and big data to make cities better—and even a little magical.

video:video.video:title: Out of Office with Brent Rose - Teched-Out Van
video:video.video:description: Brent Rose has just taken “Out of Office” to the next level. In this episode, he shows off the teched-out van he will be living in during his nascent year-long road trip across the United States. Brent gives us a fun tour of his supremely techy mobile home, including the roof-mounted solar panels, cutting edge lithium ion batteries, GPS-enabled, smartphone-connected alarm system, fingerprint-secured safe, and cutting edge stereo system.

video:video.video:title: Sunset on Pluto
video:video.video:description: New images from NASA's New Horizon probe show interesting new details of Pluto, including what might be fog and glaciers hinting at weather patterns on the frigid dwarf planet.

video:video.video:title: Electro Musician Robert DeLong Shows Off His Tricked-Out Rig
video:video.video:description: It's equal parts D.I.Y. and high-tech; electronic musician Robert DeLong shows us his awesome rig, which includes a mix of video game controllers, a cutlery tray from Ikea, two Mac minis, and more. See how it all comes together as he performs “Don’t Wait Up” from his new album "In the Cards," out Friday, September 18 on Glassnote Records.

video:video.video:title: Absurd Creatures | This Tiny Adorable Critter Is Half Kangaroo, Half Velociraptor
video:video.video:description: The jerboa looks like a cross between a mouse and a tiny kangaroo and wow, can it hop! The rodents' elongated, powerful legs can propel the little fur balls as far as six feet.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Maze Runner: Scorch Trials—Building a Post-Apocalyptic City
video:video.video:description: The second installment of “The Maze Runner” takes place in a mythical post-apocalyptic city. Find out how Weta Digital took an unusual approach to creating the vast, ruined landscape by building the entire city first, then destroying it.

video:video.video:title: All the Pluto Photos from New Horizons' First Big Data Dump
video:video.video:description: It'll take a year for New Horizons to send back all the information it gathered on Pluto when it flew by in July.

video:video.video:title: XtraCycle EdgeRunner: The Pickup Truck of Electric Bikes
video:video.video:description: The EdgeRunner by XtraCycle is a load hauling behemoth of a bike that makes pedaling that much easier with a robust electric motor assist. WIRED senior writer David Pierce puts the bike through its paces with various cargo loads.

video:video.video:title: Here's How iOS 9 Will Make Your Phone (and Life) Better
video:video.video:description: The new iPhone 6S, 6S plus and iPad Pro aren't out yet but you can update your devices to iOS 9. WIRED senior writer David Pierce explores some of the best new features and a couple you don't need.

video:video.video:title: Simply Perfect - How to Make a Jalisco Mule | Sponsored by Patrón Tequila
video:video.video:description:
Consider it a Moscow mule with a twist—mixologist David Alan shows you how to make a Jalisco mule using lime juice, ginger beer, and Patrón Reposado.
Sponsored by Patrón Tequila

video:video.video:title: Think Like a Tree - Can Namib Desert Beetles Help Us Solve Our Drought Problems?
video:video.video:description: Namib desert beetles live in an area with little ground water, so how is it that they have no trouble finding H2O? Find out how the resourceful insects use their wing scales to absorb water droplets from fog, and how we can use them as a model for combating water shortages.

video:video.video:title: Nebia - Reinventing the Shower
video:video.video:description: Startup Nebia used aerospace technology to reinvent the shower and save water. San Francisco design firm Box Clever took Nebia's rough prototypes and developed the sleek fixture that could change the way we clean up.

video:video.video:title: Absurd Creatures | Meet the Weta, an Insect as Big as a Gerbil
video:video.video:description: The tree weta, which looks like a cricket, is not cricket sized, it is the heaviest confirmed insect on earth. Males throw that weight around fighting for females, mostly by trying to dismember each other with their giant pincers.

video:video.video:title: Data Attack - Your Guide to Ashley Madison, Explained with Bad Stock Footage
video:video.video:description: What did we really find out from the Ashley Madison hack? For starters, there were only three zip codes in the U.S. with no registered users, plus the company netted $1.7 million from a full-delete feature (that didn’t actually delete). Find out what else was revealed in the hack, as told by bad stock footage.

video:video.video:title: Here's All the New Stuff From Apple's Big iPhone Event
video:video.video:description: Apple presented new a Watch partnership, its new iPad Pro and Pencil stylus, a new Apple TV and of course, the new iPhone 6S and 6S Plus with 3D Touch, 4K video and Live Photo features.

video:video.video:title: Ferris Bueller's Ferrari
video:video.video:description: You may know it as the gorgeous car Ferris Bueller and his friends drive around Chicago but to car fans it's the Ferrari 250GT California Spyder short wheelbase model, the one with the super-rare headlight covers.

video:video.video:title: Think Like a Tree - How Coral Reefs and Carbon Dioxide Can Change the Future
video:video.video:description: Most people think of carbon dioxide as a poison, but in nature it’s a building block. Find out how we can imitate coral reef by using CO2 as a raw material for the creation of concrete.

video:video.video:title: How to Not Embarrass Yourself in Front of the Robot at Work
video:video.video:description: I have been part robot since May. I've learned a lot about how robotic and human co-workers have to adjust to get along in the office of the future while piloting my $2500 Double telepresence robot. Here are my rules of robot human workplace interaction.

video:video.video:title: Absurd Creatures | The Curious Case of the Elusive, Slimy Nautilus
video:video.video:description: It hasn't been seen in more than 30 years and it lives on dead fish. No, it's not Gollum, it's called the crusty nautilus. Not because it’s brittle or irritable or anything, it’s just encrusted with a layer of slime.

video:video.video:title: How the BB-8 Toy Came to Be
video:video.video:description: The Force Awakens isn't even in theaters yet but the new Star Wars toys are already out. None is more exciting than Sphero's swivel-headed ball of cute, the BB-8 robot. Here's how the little toy company built the droid we are all looking for.

video:video.video:title: Talking Pictures | The Icy Surf Photography of Chris Burkard
video:video.video:description: Photographer Chris Burkard doesn't make the usual images of surfers. He and his crew don thick wetsuits and head for the poles to make photos of surfers paddling out in slushy cold waters off of Norway, Iceland and Chile.

video:video.video:title: Range Rover Transparent Trailer Concept
video:video.video:description: Range Rover is developing a safety concept connecting a camera on the back of trailers with a driver's rearview mirror eliminating the blindspots of towing.

video:video.video:title: Evolution of a Pony: The 2016 Ford Shelby GT350R Mustang
video:video.video:description: With a massive engine and no creature comforts like back seats to weigh it down, the Shelby GT350R is a candidate for the most fun Mustang ever. WIRED associate editor Alex Davies takes it for a spin on the famed Laguna Seca racetrack.

video:video.video:title: 2016 Chevrolet Volt
video:video.video:description: The all new redesigned 2016 Chevy Volt.

video:video.video:title: Think Like a Tree - Using Shark Skin to Fight Against Bacteria
video:video.video:description: Scientists are looking to an unlikely source for new ways to fight bacteria. Could the skin of a Galapagos shark hold the key to warding off hospital-born bacteria and superbugs?

video:video.video:title: Watch NASA Drop a Plane on Its Tail for Safety
video:video.video:description: NASA dropped a 1974 Cessna 172 airplane tail-first from 100 feet up to test emergency locator transmitters, or ELTs. Data from the drop, including high-speed video, will help researchers test ELT performance and robustness.

video:video.video:title: The Ludicrously Fast Tesla Model S P90D | Zero to 60 at Supercar Speeds
video:video.video:description: The Tesla P90D is the fastest Tesla on the market. WIRED associate editor Alex Davies gets behind the wheel to test out "ludicrous mode" which uses both of the car's electric motors for acceleration speeds normally only experienced in supercars from the likes of Ferrari and Lamborghini.

video:video.video:title: Absurd Creatures | This Leech is a Pain in the Butt for Hippos
video:video.video:description: Hippos are tough animals with tough hides. So tough that there's a species of leech that has evolved to live and feed in the only part of the hippo where the sun don't shine. Ladies and gentlemen, the life and times of the hippo butt leech.

video:video.video:title: Predicting Hurricanes in High Definition
video:video.video:description: In the decade since Hurricane Katrina, tools for tracking and modeling powerful storms have grown in sophistication and detail.

video:video.video:title: Think Like a Tree - Using Live Oak Trees as a Blueprint for Surviving Hurricanes
video:video.video:description: With sturdy, spiral trunks and deep roots that intertwine with neighboring trees, a live oak is a force to be reckoned with. Find out how architects and engineers are starting to think like a tree when designing safe and resilient structures.

video:video.video:title: The Ashley Madison Hack Explained
video:video.video:description: Hackers released the names of millions of users of the infidelity website Ashley Madison. Here's why the hackers say they dumped the data online.

video:video.video:title: 60 Years of Influential Auto Design, Up for Auction
video:video.video:description: These cars introduced new forms of beauty---many of them clever solutions to vexing technological problems---that lived on for years and even decades.

video:video.video:title: Talking Pictures | The Many Contradictions of Gitmo
video:video.video:description: Photographer Debi Cornwall made numerous trips to Guantánamo Bay Naval Base to make startlingly banal images of detainee and military personnel life. Children's jungle gyms, tiki bars and the overstuffed chair and shackles of the "Compliant Detainee Media Room."

video:video.video:title: NASA Data Viz Wizards Model the Movement of Ocean Garbage Patches
video:video.video:description: Ocean Currents Create Garbage Patches.

video:video.video:title: Absurd Creatures | Pucker Up With the Truck-Sized Ocean Sunfish
video:video.video:description: The ocean sunfish, equipped with thick, mucous-covered lips, can grow to 10 feet long and 5,000 pounds on a diet of calorie-poor jellyfish.

video:video.video:title: Simply Perfect - Vsauce3 on Comic-Con Cosplay, Doctor Who & Artists Alley | Sponsored by Patrón Tequila
video:video.video:description:
Wonder what it’s like to attend Comic-Con? Jake Roper of the YouTube channel Vsauce3 offers an insider’s look at the people who bring the event to life, from the designers who create fan art on Artists Alley to the Doctor Who-obsessed cosplayers.
Sponsored by Patrón Tequila

video:video.video:title: Simply Perfect - Superheroes of the Culinary World | Sponsored by Patrón Tequila
video:video.video:description:
San Diego chef Brian Malarkey shows us what it takes to prepare a large-scale formal dinner, served aboard an old train car, no less. Held during Comic-Con, the Patrón Secret Dining Society event brought together foodies and YouTubers like Jake Roper of Vsauce3 for a night of superhero-inspired dining.
Sponsored by Patrón Tequila

video:video.video:title: Astronauts Eat First Space Grown Salad
video:video.video:description: For the first time, astronauts ate fresh lettuce they'd grown from seed aboard the International Space Station. One small bite for man could be a giant leap for manned missions to Mars.

video:video.video:title: Big Question | Can Cats Make Us Crazy?
video:video.video:description: Cats can make you go nuts and it's not just the emotional manipulation that's driving you batty...it might be a parasite.

video:video.video:title: Earth's Selfie Satellite
video:video.video:description: NASA's DSCOVR satellite is sending back some of the most amazing images of earth ever seen, including the moon passing over our planet, beamed back from a million miles away. DSCOVR isn't just out there making pretty pictures, it's also an advanced warning system for potentially dangerous space weather.

video:video.video:title: Station to Station Full Film
video:video.video:description: Station to Station took over the Barbican Centre in London for 30 days this summer (June 27 - July 26) with a continuously evolving living exhibition. Each day of Station to Station: A 30 Day Happening, a new 15-second film was posted to @stntostn and these were brought together to create this complete 7.5 minute film. More at: www.stationtostation.com/30-dayfilm

video:video.video:title: Absurd Creatures | The Horrifying Sting of the Tarantula Hawk Wasp
video:video.video:description: In the world of horrifyingly painful stinging creatures, the tarantula hawk ranks so high that the actual scientific advice if you're stung is to lie down and scream. Dandy if you're a human, but if you are a tarantula, the wasp's prey, it's even worse.

video:video.video:title: This Wasp Mind-Controls Spiders While Eating Them Alive
video:video.video:description: Scientists don't know exactly how the larva of the Reclinervellus nielseni wasp mind-controls spiders into building a special web to protect it but they do know that they eat their hosts and steal their webs.

video:video.video:title: Alpha Geek | Capt. Katie Higgins of The Blue Angels
video:video.video:description: Marine captain Katie Higgins is the first female pilot to fly in the Blue Angels stunning air shows. She pilots “Fat Albert” a C-130 cargo transporter that is a crowd favorite for its low passes, dives and backwards taxi.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Game of Thrones: Season 5 Special FX
video:video.video:description: Find out how the visual effects came together for the end of season five on Game of Thrones, including Daenerys' elaborate and cinematic escape with her drogon.

video:video.video:title: These Guys Can Hack An E-Skateboard
video:video.video:description: A pair of security researchers can hack into some electric skateboards' Bluetooth controllers and pull the boards out from under a rider's feet.

video:video.video:title: Booze Science | Ice
video:video.video:description: Booze Science is better drinking through chemistry. WIRED articles editor Adam Rogers explores the scientific ways ice can influence a cocktail with Jennifer Colliau, beverage director at San Francisco's innovative bar The Interval at The Long Now.

video:video.video:title: Stunning Views of Dwarf Planet Ceres
video:video.video:description: Beautiful new images of Ceres, the pock-marked asteroid, are being beamed back from NASA’s Dawn probe.

video:video.video:title: Talking Pictures: Sam’s Cure
video:video.video:description: Writer Fred Vogelstein describes the moving images photographer Elinor Carucci made of his family as they seek a cannabis derived treatment for his son Sam’s epilepsy.

video:video.video:title: Hacking a "Smart" Sniper Rifle
video:video.video:description: Security researchers Runa Sandvik and Michael Auger can hack into TrackingPoint self-aiming rifles and make the famously accurate guns miss the intended target.

video:video.video:title: Henry's Premiere
video:video.video:description: A look at Oculus Story Studio's first virtual reality short film, "Henry" an animated porcupine who loves hugs.

video:video.video:title: Bubbles in Space
video:video.video:description: Astronauts aboard the International Space Station are using an ultra HD 4K camera to record experiments like this water bubble with an antacid inside.

video:video.video:title: Mercedes-Benz Urban Hunting
video:video.video:description: More than 3,200 players scattered throughout the streets of Zurich to evade a “hunter” stalking them in a Mercedes-Benz CLA Shooting Brake through a GPS game app on contestants' phones. The winner, who stayed away longest, drove off in the stalker car.

video:video.video:title: Pixels is a Love Letter to Gamers
video:video.video:description: Pixels director Chris Columbus talks to WIRED about the fun of 8-bit arcade games and building a real life Donkey Kong set for the new action comedy.

video:video.video:title: Out of Office with Brent Rose - Rideables Are So Hot Right Now. We Put Them to the Test
video:video.video:description: Electric personal transportation devices (aka “rideables”) are everywhere. We’re seeing them under everyone from Justin Bieber to J.R. Smith to Casey Neistat, but are any of them worth a damn? We put four of the most promising rideables to the test and I’ve got the scars to prove it. -Brent

video:video.video:title: Hackers Remotely Kill a Jeep on the Highway—With Me in It
video:video.video:description: Two hackers have developed a tool that can hijack a Jeep over the internet. WIRED senior writer Andy Greenberg takes the SUV for a spin on the highway while the hackers attack it from miles away.

video:video.video:title: WIRED – August 2015 Issue Preview – Welcome to the Post Natural World
video:video.video:description: Welcome to the post-natural world. In the August issue of WIRED, we explore Crispr, a new technique for editing DNA that makes it as easy as cut and paste. Ready or not, evolution is about to get an upgrade. Also this month: Mark and Jay Duplass are Hollywood’s unlikely new moguls, a WIRED writer builds an untraceable AR-15 assault rifle right here in our office, and a nonprofit that helps people from the poorest places in the world learn to be task rabbits of the 21st-century economy.

video:video.video:title: Fly Over Pluto's Mountains
video:video.video:description: Fly over Pluto's beautiful mountains and the plains of its "heart" in this amazing NASA animation built with some of the first close-up images from the New Horizons probe.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Terminator Genisys: Creating a Fully Digital Schwarzenegger
video:video.video:description: He's back—this time in a time-traveling standoff. See how Arnold Schwarzenegger faced off against a digitized version of his younger self.

video:video.video:title: Behind the Mask: Darth Vader at Comic Con
video:video.video:description: You saw him choke Comic Con goers at this year's SDCC. Get to know cosplayer Dupree Jones as he shows us what it takes to transform into Darth Vader.

video:video.video:title: "Geeks Who Drink" Teaser 2
video:video.video:description: Sharpen your minds with @Syfy's latest nerdy trivia gameshow #GeeksWhoDrink. Tune in this Thursday at 11/10c.

video:video.video:title: Ant-Man Director Says Paul Rudd is Just Right as Tiny Marvel Superhero
video:video.video:description: Ant-Man director Peyton Reed spoke with WIRED about bringing the tiny superhero to the big screen, some easter eggs for Marvel fans and how Paul Rudd preserved the wry humor of the original comic books.

video:video.video:title: "Geeks Who Drink" Teaser
video:video.video:description: Time to turn up and represent your inner nerd. Watch #GeeksWhoDrink on @Syfy this Thursday, starting at 11/10c.

video:video.video:title: New Horizons' First Close Look at Pluto
video:video.video:description: After billions of miles and nearly a decade in space New Horizons flew as close to Pluto as it ever will. The probe is already sending back the first beautiful images of the mysterious dwarf planet.

video:video.video:title: NASA's Simulator Puts All Eyes on Pluto
video:video.video:description: Watch New Horizons' historic flyby from the space probe's perspective

video:video.video:title: Hands On With Star Wars: Battlefront
video:video.video:description: WIRED senior editor Peter Rubin tests his skills in the new Star Wars: Battlefront game which was featured at Nerd HQ at San Diego Comic Con 2015.

video:video.video:title: Darth Vader Chokes Comic Con
video:video.video:description: Few could resist the asphyxiating grip of the Dark Side when Dupree Jones, who cosplays as Darth Vader, tried out the Sith lord's famous Force choke on the rebel scum of San Diego Comic Con 2015.

video:video.video:title: New Horizons’ Long Trip to Pluto
video:video.video:description: After billions of miles and nearly a decade hurtling through space the probe New Horizons will finally pass Pluto and begin to give Earth the closest look at the furthest edges of the solar system.

video:video.video:title: Out of Office with Brent Rose - Mini GoPro! Hero4 Session: Full Review, Tests, Comparison Footage
video:video.video:description: If you hate GoPro's rectangular shape, your prayers have been answered! Sort of. We took the new Hero4 Session into rivers, lakes, and surf, off cliffs and platforms, through trees and go kart courses. Our full review will tell you everything you need to know.

video:video.video:title: Mission to Pluto: The Story Behind the Historic Trip
video:video.video:description: It’s taken nine years to get there, but on July 14, 2015 the New Horizons spacecraft will finally fly by its destination: Pluto. Find out how the historic mission to Pluto happened from the people who helped launch it.

video:video.video:title: The Science of Sparklers
video:video.video:description:
An amazing mix of chemistry and physics makes it possible to hold lit sparklers which can burn at temperatures as hot as 3000 degrees Fahrenheit.
For information on the science, check out: http://www.wired.com/2014/07/the-awesome-physics-in-a-simple-sparkler/

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - Smooth Moves: Riding Insanely Fun Hoverboards
video:video.video:description: You’ve seen Justin Bieber, Kendall Jenner and JR Smith cruising on these things. What are they exactly? Are they safe? Can I buy one? WIRED Senior Writer David Pierce has the answers and tips for riding The Scoot, even the knockoffs of the knockoffs.

video:video.video:title: Massive Black Holes Whip Dark Matter Into a Frenzy
video:video.video:description: Inside a simulation of the universe's particle accelerator with WIRED Science writer Nick Stockton.

video:video.video:title: Andre Iguodala Talks Tech on and off the Court
video:video.video:description: NBA Finals MVP small forward Andre Iguodala visited WIRED to talk with Mark McClusky, Head of Operations, about the tech, including a card game app, that helped the Golden State Warriors win the 2015 championship.

video:video.video:title: What's Inside - Fireworks
video:video.video:description: Fireworks are as synonymous with the Fourth of July as hot dogs and barbecues, but what makes the decorative flashes of light burn so bright? A mix of charcoal, potassium nitrate, and sulfur, among many other ingredients.

video:video.video:title: All Work and All Play With Career Coach Rashida Jones
video:video.video:description: Rashida Jones works. A lot! She took a break from acting, producing and writing to talk to WIRED about how to stay inspired at the office, good career advice and her fantasy jobs.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Issue Preview – July 2015 – All Work & All Play, With Rashida Jones
video:video.video:description: WIRED presents the essential manual to finding happiness at work, with your career coach, Rashida Jones. Optimize your brain, your relationships, and your stuff to achieve a state of occupational bliss. Also this month: How Ebola survivors’ DNA could help treat other deadly viruses, billionaire VCs battle to capture massive ROI, one family’s epic quest to cure their son’s epilepsy, and more.

video:video.video:title: One Minute of Stunning Ultra HD Video From Space
video:video.video:description: This week NASA released a first look of ultra-high definition video shot on and from the International Space Station. Here, 60 seconds of the most breathtaking new footage.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Jurassic World: Using Motion-Capture to Create Realistic Dinosaurs
video:video.video:description: “Jurassic World” debuted with a record-shattering opening weekend, netting nearly half a billion dollars. See how Industrial Light & Magic used motion capture to help design the complex dinosaurs, including the genetically modified Indominus rex.

video:video.video:title: The Bloody Illegal World of Sand Mining
video:video.video:description: Photographer Adam Ferguson documents the environmental and human costs of illegal sand mining in India where rapid growth fuels a sometimes violent black market for one of the most basic raw building materials.

video:video.video:title: Would Jurassic World’s New Dinosaur Win in an Epic Showdown?
video:video.video:description: Who would win in a battle of the dinos? “Jurassic World” consultant and renowned paleontologist Jack Horner gives us his picks, if the new “Jurassic World” dinosaur Indominus rex came face-to-face with a Tyrannosaurus rex and a velociraptor.

video:video.video:title: The Director of ‘Jurassic World’ on Tackling the Beloved Franchise
video:video.video:description: When Colin Trevorrow saw Jurassic Park as a teenager it sparked his interest in the power of film. He spoke with WIRED about taking on the franchise and getting the audience to cheer for their favorite dinosaurs.

video:video.video:title: Creating Jurassic World’s New Genetically Modified Dinosaur
video:video.video:description: Legendary paleontologist Jack Horner—the real-life inspiration behind original “Jurassic Park” protagonist Alan Grant—explains how they conceived the genetically modified dino, Indominus rex, in the new film “Jurassic World."

video:video.video:title: Facebook and Oculus Want Your Head and Hands in Virtual Space
video:video.video:description: Facebook and Oculus unveiled the official Rift virtual reality headset and introduced Touch, a set of prototype controllers that could make virtual reality more physically immersive.

video:video.video:title: Maybe These Aren’t the Droids We are Looking For
video:video.video:description: Why do humans make robots in their own image? At the 2015 Darpa Robotic Challenge, most of the robots competing to open doors, walk over rubble, and drive a vehicle walked like humans. And they fell over a lot. WIRED writer Matt Simon looks at why two-legged robots seem like a good idea.

video:video.video:title: Unnecessarily Rushed Explanations - The Most Difficult Video Game of All Time: Super Hexagon
video:video.video:description: Super Hexagon is not a video game for the easily discouraged. You die early and often until eventually (hopefully) you get into the swing of things. WIRED editor Chris Kohler explains why it’s the most difficult video game of all time.

video:video.video:title: What's Inside - Sriracha
video:video.video:description: There’s a reason Sriracha is more popular than its fiery competitors. Featuring a mix of red jalapeño chile peppers, flavor profiles that ignite all five senses, and vinegar for an extended shelf-life, we break down the ingredients that make up the rooster sauce.

video:video.video:title: The Coldest Place on Earth | Talking Pictures
video:video.video:description: New Zealand based photographer Amos Chapple traveled to Siberia, to make images of life in Oymakon, Russia, said be the coldest place on earth. There hardy residents endure winters with 21 hours of darkness and temperatures can plunge to –90 Fahrenheit.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - Video Recap: Apple’s Biggest Announcements From WWDC
video:video.video:description: THE BIGGEST APPLE developer event of the year kicked off this morning at Moscone Center in San Francisco. WIRED’s David Pierce attended the WWDC keynote, and he gives us a quick recap on all the news. There are enhancements coming to Apple’s desktop OS, it’s iOS software, and a big update to the three-months-old Apple Watch that includes support for native apps.

video:video.video:title: Three Things to Know About Apple Music
video:video.video:description: WIRED senior writer David Pierce explains how Apple, the most powerful company in music, is shaking up listening again with its new Music platform which combines streaming audio, worldwide human-curated radio and a social network of artists and fans.

video:video.video:title: The Untold Design Story of the Final WTC Building
video:video.video:description: WHEN BJARKE INGELS set out to create the fourth and final skyscraper at the reborn World Trade Center earlier this year, he faced the same dilemma that has burdened every architect who has ventured onto New York’s most hallowed and expensive construction site.

video:video.video:title: Out of Office with Brent Rose - Best & Worst Foods for California’s Drought
video:video.video:description: California is in an unprecedented drought, but you gotta eat, right? Well, some foods use way more water than others. We chewed through a ton of data to make this bite-sized video. For you! -Brent

video:video.video:title: I Made an Untraceable AR-15 'Ghost Gun' In My Office
video:video.video:description: WIRED senior writer Andy Greenberg puts new homemade gunsmithing tools to the test as he tries three ways of building an untraceable AR-15 semi-automatic rifle---a so-called "ghost gun"---while skirting all gun control laws.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Mad Max Fury Road: Choreographing Complex Stunts & Car Chases
video:video.video:description: Shot mostly in Africa with real vehicles and complex stunts, “Mad Max: Fury Road” brings a high intensity to the post-apocalyptic franchise. Mike Seymour breaks down the complicated camerawork and VFX behind the action-adventure flick.

video:video.video:title: NYC’s Best & Worst Ways to Commute
video:video.video:description: What’s the best way to commute in NYC? We had five Queens residents take various modes of transportation, including Uber, a cab, the ferry, a bike, and the subway to see which one came out on top.

video:video.video:title: Joshuah Bearman on The Rise and Fall of Silk Road
video:video.video:description: Author Joshuah Bearman discusses his two part techno-noir series on the rise and fall of the online drug bazaar Silk Road. Music by - Julia Kent - Salute

video:video.video:title: How Google Wants to Turn Everything Into a Wearable
video:video.video:description: Google thinks the future of wearables might be making the clothes we already wear connected. It¹s Project Jacquard with Levis may herald a future when a swipe on a sleeve makes a phone call and your pants are talking to the cloud.

video:video.video:title: Data Attack - How Huge is Minecraft? We Explain, in 8-bit
video:video.video:description: With more than 100,000,000 players and 54,000,000 units sold, Minecraft is one of the biggest video games on the planet. Just how big? We break down the numbers behind the wildly popular game.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Issue Preview June 2015 - Inside the Magic Factory
video:video.video:description: This year, Industrial Light & Magic celebrates 40 years of creating the impossible. In WIRED's June issue, we present an oral history of ILM, and look at how George Lucas’ little DIY effects shop changed movies forever. Also this month: Silk Road mastermind Ross Ulbricht's journey from drug kingpin to convicted criminal, Senator Cory Booker's attempt to drag the Senate into the 21st century, the global battle over one of Earth’s most plentiful resources, and much more. #WIRED2306 #WIRED

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Tomorrowland: Behind the FX of the Futuristic World
video:video.video:description: See how Industrial Light & Magic created the futuristic tech and magical world in Brad Bird’s Tomorrowland.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - Easier Pedaling With the Faraday E-Bike
video:video.video:description: More people are using bikes for transportation and electric bikes can make the trip a lot easier. While expensive, the Faraday Porteur is one of the most elegant and zippy e-bikes we’ve tried.

video:video.video:title: Unnecessarily Rushed Explanations - The Most Disgusting Video Game of All Time: Hotline Miami
video:video.video:description: It’s reminiscent of old Grand Theft Auto games, but Hotline Miami is in a league of its own. It tricks you into thinking it’s cute, but don’t be fooled, it's one of the most gruesome and bloody video games of all time.

video:video.video:title: Out of Office with Brent Rose - Fun With Powdered Alcohol: You Can Stop Being Scared Now
