video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - How Do You Make a Video Go Viral? Unruly Media’s Sarah Wood Explains
video:video.video:description: Founder and COO of Unruly Media, Sarah Wood, explains the myths, value, and impact of video content in an evolving digital landscape.

video:video.video:title: Bonus Content: See How to Build Captain Kirk’s Chair from Star Trek Continues with Vic Mignogna
video:video.video:description: It’s more than just a prop. Vic Mignogna, who stars as Captain Kirk in “Star Trek Continues,” shows us the famous Captain’s chair and explains how the set designer re-created a replica of the original version, down to the hand-poured control buttons.

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - The Thiel Fellows Get an Inside Look at Silicon Valley on a Field Trip to the Google Campus
video:video.video:description: The Thiel fellows get a dose of Silicon Valley life as they visit Google’s collaborative workspace, The Garage. After a demo of Google Glass, the group gets hands-on with an innovation exercise to hone their creativity and team-building skills.

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - The Thiel Fellows Visit TechShop in SF & Gain Access to Innovative Equipment & Technology
video:video.video:description: Back in San Francisco, fellows Shantanu Bala and Kaushik Tiwari visit the community workshop and prototyping studio TechShop. As they tour the space and check out equipment, Shantanu develops new ideas that he can apply to his project of building new computer interfaces that use a sense of touch to get information.

video:video.video:title: Meet the Cast & Crew of Star Trek Continues with Vic Mignogna
video:video.video:description: Get to know the dedicated cast and crew that are bringing Star Trek Continues to life. Plus, find out which cast member spent time on set of the original series when his dad starred as Scotty.

video:video.video:title: What's Inside - Red Bull
video:video.video:description: The energy drink purports to "give you wings," and it has a close, personal relationship with vodka. But it isn't the sugar that amps you up—it's good, old-fashioned caffeine.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Death to the Superhero Comic-Book Movie … But Not All Comic-Book Movies
video:video.video:description: It’s hard for him to admit, but Angry Nerd just doesn’t need anymore Marvel or DC comic book movies. Instead of another big budget flick with an oversaturated superhero, why not look elsewhere for solid source material? Case in point: The excellent, new comic-to-silver-screen adaptation, Snowpiercer.

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - Talking with Darby Schumacher, the 18-Year-Old Thiel Fellowship Finalist Who Wants to Prevent SIDS
video:video.video:description: Eighteen-year-old Darby Schumacher is trying to create a safer and healthier world for newborns. The 2014 Thiel Fellowship finalist is working to develop an alert system that tracks vital signs in babies to help combat Sudden Infant Death Syndrome. The Tennessee native explains what prompted her to start the project and why she wants to become an entrepreneur.

video:video.video:title: WIRED - July 2014 Issue Teaser - The Code
video:video.video:description: A new generation of online experiences demands a new set of rules for stylish and proper behavior. Guest voice of reason Jerry Seinfeld guides us through Instagram, wearables, Tinder, Secret, and more in a quest to help you vanquish your inner glasshole. Also this month: one doctor’s controversial quest to save lives and three daring photographers risk arrest to preserve America’s Cold War legacy. Music - “Soft Gems Pt. 1” By: Mujeres

video:video.video:title: Expedition Gadget Lab - 2014 Kawasaki KLR Special Edition
video:video.video:description:
We set out on a three-day, off-road adventure into the Cascade Mountains of Washington State to test the best gear for getting away from it all.
Music - “Let the Black Horse Ride” Performed By: BROTHERS NYC (brothersnyc.com)

video:video.video:title: New Rules for Stylish and Proper Behavior with Guest Voice of Reason: Jerry Seinfeld
video:video.video:description: As technology pioneers, we are inundated with new gadgets, services, apps, messaging, games, and media. We’re doxing, vaping, and Lyfting. And that means there are new rules for how to behave. Is it ok to answer an email during dinner? Is Google Glass ever cool? We got some help from Jerry Seinfeld, keen observer of social mores and foibles, on how to cope with modern technology… and whether it’s ok to “Like” a Facebook posting that someone died.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - What’s a Robot in 2014? Rodney Brooks and Andrew McAfee Debate
video:video.video:description: What is a robot in 2014? Founder, chairman, and CTO of Rethink Robotics Rodney Brooks and co-author of The Second Machine Age, Andrew McAfee, sit down to discuss the past, present, and future of robotics.

video:video.video:title: RetroGrade - Remember When a 29-pound Portable Computer was Light?
video:video.video:description: A fully functional portable computer that weighs in at only 29 lbs.? Now we’re talking. With features like word processing and a calculator, the 1984 LCD-286 PC computer was like carrying a filing cabinet with you on the go.

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - Are You an Adult or a Kid? The Thiel Fellows Gear Up for Orientation … and Adulthood
video:video.video:description: The fellows who’ve moved into the campus house start to settle in—all the while gearing up for orientation. In this episode, the teens hear advice from current and past fellows on the challenges they'll face, including how to make the most of their $100,000 grants.

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - Teens Move into One House to Pursue Their Dreams in Silicon Valley as the 2014 Thiel Fellows
video:video.video:description: As the 2014 Thiel Fellows prepare to move to San Francisco for the summer, the reality of the fellowship starts to sink in. Having to drop out of school, dealing with parental judgment—is it all really worth it to pursue their ideas and projects in Silicon Valley?

video:video.video:title: Tour the USS Enterprise From Star Trek Continues w/Vic Mignogna
video:video.video:description: From the transporter room to the sick bay, take a full tour of the stage used in Star Trek Continues. Modeled after the original set used in the late '60s, Vic Mignogna takes us behind the painstakingly recreated USS Enterprise.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Why Clint Eastwood’s “Jersey Boys” is Destined to Crash & Burn on the Big Screen
video:video.video:description: Musicals. They’re great. But jukebox musicals? That’s an entirely different—and often terrible—story. Even with Clint Eastwood behind the camera of the new stage-to-film rendition of Jersey Boys, there’s only so much Dirty Harry can do for the destined-to-flop silver screen adaptation.

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - Say Hello to Rebecca Jolitz, the 19-year-old Thiel Fellow Who Wants to Disrupt the Satellite Industry
video:video.video:description: With degrees in mathematics and physics from U.C. Berkeley, 19-year-old Rebecca Jolitz is planning to revolutionize the satellite development industry. Get to know the 2014 Thiel Fellow and find out what first inspired her love of science.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Tech Entrepreneur & Investor Chris Dixon Explains Why You Should Give a Damn About Bitcoin
video:video.video:description: Chris Dixon, general partner at venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, thinks you should reconsider the power of bitcoin. In conversation with WIRED’s Steven Levy, the tech entrepreneur and investor explains why the digital payment system has the potential to enable new behaviors and innovations.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Tumblr’s David Karp on Why He Doesn’t Regret the Yahoo! Sale & Empowering Creators
video:video.video:description: At BizCon 2014, Tumblr CEO and co-founder David Karp sat down with WIRED senior writer Steven Levy to talk about why he doesn’t regret the Yahoo! sale, how his platform empowers creators, and the importance of enabling users.

video:video.video:title: RetroGrade - Madden Doesn't Have Anything on this Old-School Football Video Game
video:video.video:description: In 1978 Mattel elevated handheld gaming to the next level with the Football 2. Realistic game sounds, plus the ability to pass the ball? Touchdown!

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - Meet Catherine Ray—A 2014 Thiel Fellow and Mathematics Wunderkind
video:video.video:description: Seventeen-year-old Catherine Ray just received a $100,000 Thiel Fellowship. Armed with a B.S. in computational physics, the mathematics whiz is planning to fix everything that’s wrong with wheelchairs. Get to know the teen technorati.

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - Get to Know 19-year-old Tech Whiz & 2014 Thiel Fellow Lucy Guo
video:video.video:description: She’s double-majoring in computer science and human-computer interaction at Carnegie Mellon. She also just won a $100,000 Thiel Fellowship to develop a platform for customizable education-based games. Get to know teen technorati Lucy Guo.

video:video.video:title: Take a Sneak Peek at Vic Mignogna’s Mirror, Mirror Resolution in Star Trek Continues
video:video.video:description: The attention is all in the details on set at Star Trek Continues. As the cast and crew begin to film the latest episode—a follow-up to the episode “Mirror, Mirror,” which took place in the second season of the original series—see how Vic Mignogna and team re-created the incredibly detailed set.

video:video.video:title: Catch Vic Mignogna Behind the Scenes in the Series Star Trek Continues
video:video.video:description: Intended to pick up where the original show left off, the web series “Star Trek Continues” has brought about a wave of nostalgic appreciation for the classic sci-fi show. After a successful Kickstarter campaign and now, with two full webisodes under its belt, the show, by producer/director/super fan/star Vic Mignogna, is ushering in brand-new voyages of the starship Enterprise.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Is Darth Disney Destroying Star Wars’ Expanded Universe?
video:video.video:description: With Darth Disney holding the keys to Star Wars, the fate of the expanded universe is at stake. Since the movies are only a fraction of the franchise’s stories, Angry Nerd makes a desperate plea to the only one who can help save the unabridged material: George Lucas.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - X-Men: Days of Future Past: The Sentinels’ Complicated Follicle Animation
video:video.video:description: In X-Men: Days of Future Past, the mutant clan goes head-to-head with the Sentinels—a group of dystopian-era robots. Effects experts MPC created the Sentinels’ special effects using a follicle-like animation, comprised of tiny scales. Mike Seymour explains how they accomplished the technically complicated designs.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - eBay’s R.J. Pittman on the Future of Shopping
video:video.video:description: WIRED senior writer Steven Levy talks with eBay’s R.J. Pittman on the future of shopping, the growth of mobile, and how to build an engaging experience in the digital marketplace.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Hardeep Walia on Investing In Ideas
video:video.video:description: CEO and co-founder of Motif Investing, Hardeep Walia, explains the concept behind his company, which allows users to invest in ideas on one of the first social investing platforms.

video:video.video:title: RetroGrade - Why the Atari 2600 Is One of the Best Video Game Consoles, Ever
video:video.video:description: Long before the PlayStation 4 and Xbox One, the Atari 2600 was heralded as the next generation of gaming. Look no further than the sweet joystick and the detailed graphics to see why it’s considered one of the holy grails of video game consoles.

video:video.video:title: What's Inside - Slim Jim
video:video.video:description: It’s four inches of spicy, salted, processed meat, but is there actually beef inside the tiny stick? Well, that depends on your definition of meat.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Why Edge of Tomorrow is of the Greatest Movie About Video Games, Ever
video:video.video:description: The new sci-fi flick Edge of Tomorrow is basically a sci-fi rip-off of Groundhog Day, but with more Tom Cruise and less Bill Murray. And somehow, it manages to establish itself as one of the best movies about a video game, ever.

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - The Thiel Fellowship Finalists Leave S.F. & Head Back to Reality
video:video.video:description: After a weekend of activities and final pitches, the 40 students get ready to pack up their things and head back to reality until the 20 fellowships are awarded. In this episode, the students reflect back on what they’ve learned over the past few days, and what they’ll do if chosen as a 2014 Thiel Fellow.

video:video.video:title: WIRED by Design
video:video.video:description: Condé Nast présents WIRED by Design, a two-day live magazine exploring the intersection of cuture and design. Held from September 29-October 1 WxD will feature personal stories from today’s most influential creative thinkers — from architects and filmmakers to artists and chefs — along with wide–ranging conversations, live performances, and amazing meals. For more information visit live.wired.com.

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - 20 Teens Win $100K: Announcing the 2014 Thiel Fellows
video:video.video:description: The deliberations are over and the judges are ready to notify the 2014 Thiel Fellowship winners via Skype. Find out which 20 kids will have their lives changed forever as they win a $100,000 grant and drop out of school to pursue their dreams.

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - The Thiel Fellowship Finalists Go One-on-One with the Mentors
video:video.video:description: The lightning pitches are over, but the finalists continue to sweat in the mentor matches. Judges and industry head honchos meet with each of the 40 students to find out more about their projects. Can the fellowship finalists effectively articulate their concepts and business plans, or will the tough questions and high-pressure one-on-ones prove to be too much?

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - Tensions Rising: Final Run-Throughs & Pitch Preparations
video:video.video:description: It’s almost time for the lightning pitches, but as the pressure mounts can the Thiel Fellowship hopefuls keep their cool? In this episode, the finalists run through their strategies—and lack thereof—as they get ready to present to the judges. Plus, finalists Alexander Koren and Andrew Ninh explain their medical- and tech-based projects.

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - The Two-Minute Lightning Pitch
video:video.video:description: The big day is finally here and the finalists only have 2 minutes to convince judges that they should be one of 20 to receive a $100,000 Thiel Fellowship. As the students take the stage, see who stands out—and who comes up short—in the final lightning pitches.

video:video.video:title: RetroGrade - Before the i-Everything, There Was Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak & the Apple lle
video:video.video:description: Remember when Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak were the new kids on the block? In the early ’80s they debuted the Apple IIe, blowing away the competition. RetroGrade takes a look at the “modern” technology that helped set the industry benchmark for personal computing.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Maleficent: Re-creating Fully Digital Characters
video:video.video:description: Angelina Jolie stars in Disney’s new Maleficent, featuring a forest world of detailed visual effects. Mike Seymour delves into how facial movement experts Digital Domain, worked to re-create realistic, fully digital counterparts to the story’s three fairies.

video:video.video:title: What's Inside - Hybrid Engines
video:video.video:description: Starting a hybrid car is as easy as pushing a button, but what’s really beneath the hood? For starters, a 100-lb rechargeable battery pack containing smaller nickel-metal hydride and lithium-ion batteries, similar to those in your cell phone.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Why Disney Needs to Make More Movies About Classic Villains
video:video.video:description: The House of Mouse might be onto something: Forget the hero and make the villain the star. Disney’s new film Maleficent does just that and it actually…kind of…works. Angry Nerd explains the pros of putting the evil queens and wicked witches front and center.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Godzilla: Creating the Animalistic and Masculine Kaiju Monster
video:video.video:description: After Roland Emmerich missed the mark with Godzilla in 1998, we had reason to be skeptical of Gareth Edwards’ new remake. Fxguide’s Mike Seymour goes inside the special effects behind the latest incarnation, in which effects company MPC designed the largest Godzilla yet, featuring an animalistic appearance with anthropomorphized traits.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - The Madness of the Timeline Mashup in the New X-Men
video:video.video:description: Angry Nerd has been to the future and he brings back an important message: don’t see the new X-Men movie. With a scrambled timeline and inclusion of too many sub-franchises, the film adds a new dimension to the “days of future past” continuum: straight confusion.

video:video.video:title: WIRED - June 2014 Issue Teaser - The Future of VR is Here
video:video.video:description:
We’ve long imagined a device that renders virtual reality that's indistinguishable from the outside world. In the June issue, Senior Editor Peter Rubin explores the Oculus Rift—a VR headset doing just that. Also this month: creating a museum from the ruins of 2,983 lives, the surprising science of the hangover, and the quantum computer that maybe isn’t.
Music: "On Pagaie" Performed By: HUMANS (http://dashumans.com/)

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Why the New Godzilla Movie Won’t Suck
video:video.video:description: The makers of the new Godzilla movie are taking great pains to telegraph their deep reverence for kaiju cinema. In other words, they want us to know they won’t screw it up like Roland Emmerich did in 1998. Angry Nerd makes the case for why we should believe them.

video:video.video:title: What Remains - The 9/11 Museum
video:video.video:description:
Creating a memorial from the ruins of 2,983 lives: that's the difficult task faced by the creators of the 9/11 Museum. On the eve of its opening, we speak with director Alice Greenwald and designer Jake Barton about how to commemorate a tragic experience without recreating it.
Music: "Sun Will Set" written performed by Zoe Keating From the album - One Cello x 16: Natoma (c) 2005 020202 Music (ASCAP). All rights reserved

video:video.video:title: What's Inside - Vodka
video:video.video:description: It’s the preferred poison of Russians, dieters, and college freshmen, but what’s actually inside the fire water? It's rarely potatoes, actually. At its purest, it's mostly ethanol that has been distilled from wheat, rye, or corn and diluted with water. Find out what else is inside the clear spirit.

video:video.video:title: How Oculus Solved Virtual Reality
video:video.video:description:
The 1990s saw the rise—and fall—of virtual reality. While everyone could imagine a technology that allowed us to be somewhere else, no one was able to make it happen. No one, that is, until an 18-year-old named Palmer Luckey invented the Oculus Rift. We speak with Luckey and other Oculus employees about how they managed to crack one of technology's toughest riddles and make VR feasible for the first time.
Music: "Disco Kerosene" Performed By Circa Tapes (http://circatapes.bandcamp.com/)

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - Getting Over Stage Fright
video:video.video:description: With the two-minute lightning pitches fast approaching, the 40 Thiel Fellowship finalists are beginning to feel the pressure. In this episode, they partake in icebreaker and team-building games to help calm nerves and prep for their big onstage speeches. Also, finalists Ryan Orbuch, Thomas Hunt, and Jake Davidson tell us about their tech-and science-focused projects.

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - The LEGO Challenge: Creative Problem-Solving
video:video.video:description: In this episode of Teen Technorati, the 40 finalists are split up into teams and tasked with building a bridge made out of LEGO. Only one team emerges as the winner, but during the challenge the finalists’ leadership and problem-solving skills begin to surface. Plus, fellowship hopefuls Ishaan Gulrajani, Lucy Guo, Darby Schumacher, and Catherine Ray explain the concepts behind their individual Thiel projects.

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - Meet the 2014 Thiel Fellowship Finalists
video:video.video:description: 20 winners. $100,000 each. The chance to bring an idea to life. We follow 40 student finalists as they compete for a coveted and controversial Thiel Fellowship. Their projects range from cancer research to new app technology, but there's just one catch if they win—they'll have to drop out of school. Meet the 2014 Thiel Fellowship finalists.

video:video.video:title: Teen Technorati - 2014 Thiel Fellowship Documentary Series Teaser
video:video.video:description: Watch a preview of our new documentary series, Teen Technorati, which follows 40 students under the age of 20 as they compete for a Thiel Fellowship. Created by investor Peter Thiel, the $2 million fund awards $100,000 to 20 winners who will have to drop out of school to further develop their individual medical, technology, and design-based projects. From team challenges to a lightning pitch in front of the judges, see who makes the cut as the next generation of young, innovative entrepreneurs.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at Ducati & the Technology Behind One of the Fastest Production Motorcycles in the World
video:video.video:description: The 195-horsepower engine isn’t exactly meant for a daily commute. But Ducati’s 1199 Panigale S has a slew of features and the aerodynamics, torque, and weight reduction to make it one of the fastest production motorcycles in the world. Transportation editor Damon Lavrinc tests out the bike and talks to Ducati designers to see how they engineered one of the lightest street motorcycles on the market.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - The Greatest Fictional Characters Ever All in One Show? Sign Me Up
video:video.video:description: Character crossovers and storyline mash-ups are nothing new. But if the premise has been done before, are the character overlaps and reincarnations worth a watch? Angry Nerd makes the case for metaphysical mash-ups, including Showtime’s new “Penny Dreadful.”

video:video.video:title: Design FX - The Amazing Spider-Man 2: Transforming Jamie Foxx into the Villainous Electro
video:video.video:description: In The Amazing Spider-Man 2, Jamie Foxx stars as Electro, the glowing antagonist to Andrew Garfield’s Spidey. In this video, learn how Sony Pictures Imageworks used a combination of makeup and CGI to turn the Academy Award winner into a blue, electrically-charged villain--with inspiration from lightning, neurological networks, and nebulas.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Networks Somehow Find Another Way to Resurrect Old Shows
video:video.video:description: When a TV show goes off the air, it's supposed to stay dead. Unless it gets syndicated. But networks don't seem aware of this rule anymore, with resurrections of "24" and "Heroes" on the way. Angry Nerd does not approve of this turn of events.

video:video.video:title: Game|Life - Excavating the Atari E.T. Video Game Burial Site
video:video.video:description: It’s been dubbed The Great Video Game Burial of 1983, but did Atari really toss millions of cartridges of its biggest flop: E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial? Chris Kohler is onsite to witness an excavation of the landfill to see if the joke’s really on us, and to talk with those involved with the project, including original game designer Howard Scott Warshaw.

video:video.video:title: Game|Life - Teaser: Excavating the Atari E.T. Video Game Burial Site
video:video.video:description: In 1983 after the critical and commercial failure of Atari’s E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial video game, the company allegedly dumped millions of cartridges into a landfill in Alamogordo, N.M. Now, more than 30 years later, the site is being excavated and filmed for an upcoming docu-series by The Incredible Hulk screenwriter Zak Penn. The day before the big dig we headed south to talk with Penn about the urban legend. Plus, check out our exclusive first look at the excavation site.

video:video.video:title: What's Inside - Inkjet Cartridges
video:video.video:description: Inkjet cartridges are comprised of 95 percent water, but what’s inside the other 5 percent? We break apart the compact containers to find out what’s inside the mostly liquid assets.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Why Exactly Is Parkour Not a Film Genre Yet?
video:video.video:description: In Brick Mansions, parkour co-founder David Belle shows off his wall-climbing, window-jumping, rail-surfing action skills. So why isn't Belle the new Bruce Lee? This should be the greatest genre in cinema history. Angry Nerd blames the French.

video:video.video:title: May 2014 Business Issue: Trust Me
video:video.video:description: From Airbnb to Lyft, the sharing economy is rewiring the way we interact with each other. In the May issue, Executive Editor Jason Tanz delves into the phenomenon of entrusting strangers with our most valuable possessions, personal experiences - and our very lives. Also this month: an inside look at the algorithms and formulas that Twitter and Facebook use to build the perfect feed, the story of a Silicon Valley startup struggling to survive, and the oral history of Mystery Science Theater 3000.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Optogenetics and Enhancing Brain Functions
video:video.video:description: With optogenetics, the ability to restore and enhance brain function is becoming a reality. In this World Economic Forum discussion, Nature magazine neuroscience editor I-han Chou explains how the radical method works and the ethical issues it could cause.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - How Hollywood Can Get Evil Twins Right
video:video.video:description: Put a bit of facial hair (or swap hair color) for your protagonist and you get an evil twin. But just because you can doesn't mean you should. The Angry Nerd describes the slippery slope from plot twist to lazy trope.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Persuasive Gaming
video:video.video:description: In this World Economic Forum discussion, game designer and Georgia Tech professor Ian Bogost explains why we should look to video games to help address complex social issues.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Hasbro, Your "Magic: The Gathering" Movie Is Murdering My Childhood
video:video.video:description: First Transformers, then G.I. Joe, now Magic: The Gathering? When will Hasbro learn that a successful game or toy does not equal a successful movie franchise?

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Curing Unhappiness
video:video.video:description: Is it possible to scientifically prevent depression? In this World Economic Forum discussion, University of Oxford molecular psychiatrist Jonathan Flint explains the research he’s doing to uncover the genetic and biological basis of disorders like depression, in order to help develop better therapies.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at the Netatmo Weather Station App
video:video.video:description: Sorry Apple, sometimes your standard iPhone weather app just doesn’t cut it. Aside from the expected temperature and humidity metrics, Netatmo’s Weather Station app also offers data on sound pollution and CO2 concentration.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Captain America: The Winter Soldier: Staging the Helicarrier Crash
video:video.video:description: Industrial Light & Magic was tasked with updating the helicarriers in the new film Captain America: The Winter Soldier. FXguide’s Mike Seymour talks to the visual effects company to find out what new details were added to the S.H.I.E.L.D. aircrafts, and how the effects team created a digital modeling environment for the epic helicarrier crash scene.

video:video.video:title: What's Inside - Tear Gas
video:video.video:description: It was a weapon of choice in the first World War, and these days, law enforcement uses a less potent recipe of tear gas to pacify a room or control a crowd. Discover what’s inside the sensory-attacking irritant that can be deadly if used at high concentrations.

video:video.video:title: Science Friction WIRED Edition: How to Brainwash Someone
video:video.video:description:
In Captain America: The Winter Soldier, Steve Rogers’ sidekick-turned-nemesis undergoes drastic brainwashing to become The Winter Soldier. But is it really possible to completely change someone’s attitudes and beliefs? In this special WIRED edition of Science Friction, host Rusty Ward dives into the science behind brainwashing.
Click here to check out more Science Friction.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - The Problem with Game of Thrones
video:video.video:description: There’s a massive publishing gap in the books that Game of Thrones is based off of, and Angry Nerd is concerned that the show could catch up to the plot before the next book is out. But, one simple solution could solve everything.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Breakthroughs in Nanomedicine
video:video.video:description: In this World Economic Forum discussion, the University of Oxford’s Dr. Sonia Trigueros challenges the way we think about antibiotics and offers an alternative using the power of nanotechnology.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Unlocking Brain Data
video:video.video:description: By implanting a tiny computer chip into the brain and decoding the data that’s produced, Brown neuroscientist John Donoghue is hoping to help people with paralysis reconnect to the world around them. In this World Economic Forum discussion he explains how.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Noah: Controlling an Epic Rain-Making System with a Single App
video:video.video:description: And on the eighth day, we got apps. Fxguide’s Mike Seymour details the how the upcoming blockbuster, Noah, was able to control the mechanics of a giant custom rain machine in a studio that size of two football fields with the use of a single iPad app.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Captain America’s Unrealistic Vibranium Shield
video:video.video:description: Angry Nerd is ready to demote Captain America from his current rank to lieutenant. In the Marvel superhero’s newest movie adaptation, his vibranium shield defies everything that physics and materials science has taught us. Angry Nerd calls blasphemy on the ingredient-altered shield.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at Evernote’s Triangle Commuter Bag
video:video.video:description: All it took was a little geometry to perfect the adult man’s alternative to a backpack. The Evernote messenger bag features a triangular shape that offers stability and keeps the bag upright when you set it down.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at the Reelight GO Bike Light
video:video.video:description: Elevate bike gear with functional front and taillights in a sleek, smart design that snaps together easily with magnets.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Neil deGrasse Tyson on Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey
video:video.video:description: Astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson sits down to talk about the cultural importance of Carl Sagan’s Cosmos: A Personal Journey, and how he plans to carry on the legacy with his new version of the transformative science exploration show.

video:video.video:title: WIRED April 2014 - Coal: It’s Dangerous, It’s Dirty, and It’s the Future of Clean Energy
video:video.video:description: Solar, wind, and nuclear don’t make climate change worse, but they don’t meet the world’s energy needs. What can? Coal, and in the April issue Charles C. Mann writes about cleaning up the dirty, cheap fuel. Also this month: keeping your garden green, how mobile messaging captured our kids (and $19 billion from Facebook), and Mike Judge takes on Silicon Valley.

video:video.video:title: What's Inside - Nair Hair Removal
video:video.video:description: You know it’s for “short shorts,” but what are the chemical compounds that actually make up the no-shave follicle-removing cream? A handful of skin repair agents and hair removal ingredients intended to leave skin soft and silky smooth.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Fox News’ Abundant & Unnecessary Use of Big-Area Touch Screens
video:video.video:description: Hollywood is always trying to sell us crazy computer interfaces. Wavy hands and holograms? Never gonna happen. But now Fox News is in on the game, too—and the Angry Nerd is unfairly unbalanced about the network's giant, newsgathering touch screens.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at the Coravin 1000 Wine Saver
video:video.video:description: Oxygen is your friend. Unless you’re wine. The Coravin 1000 forces the frenemies to play nice by penetrating the cork with a long needle and pushing argon in, allowing the wine to flow out without opening the entire bottle.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at Suck UK’s 3-D Dinosaur Cookie Cutters
video:video.video:description: Tykes can construct an edible Jurassic park with these 3-D cookie cutters that create easy-to-assemble dino shapes. Plus, the little ones will get a firsthand lesson in extinction once they devour the after-school treats.

video:video.video:title: What's Inside - Red Wine
video:video.video:description: Oenophiles wax poetic about the look, feel, smell, and taste of red wine. But what’s actually inside the drink? Dozens of complicated molecules from the grape’s juice, seeds, and skin. Oh, and alcohol.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - The Veronica Mars Movie Project and the Pitfalls of Crowdfunding Films
video:video.video:description: Veronica Mars fans pledged more than $5 million on Kickstarter to get a film adaptation of the show off the ground. And while Angry Nerd is all for crowdfunding for a good cause, when it comes to fans calling the shots in return for financial backing, the money-making model might end up causing more harm than good.

video:video.video:title: Inside Innovation - CuteCircuit: Trendspotting From Tech to Fashion [Sponsored Content]
video:video.video:description:
CuteCircuit co-founder and creative director Francesca Rosella believes in technology you can wear. She explains how, with the help of co-founder Ryan Genz, CuteCircuit is able to create interactive fashion—like a dress that’s illuminated by LED lights or a skirt that displays a message—with technology that integrates seamlessly into garments.
Brought to you by Intel

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Creating a Digital Ecology That Works
video:video.video:description: Should people have the same rights and obligations online as they do in the real world? MIT computer scientist Alex “Sandy” Pentland explains how developing social networks as trusted networks will help establish a sustainable digital ecology for years to come.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at the TomTom Multisport HRM GPS Watch
video:video.video:description: Aimed at helping multisport athletes improve their training, the GPS-enabled timepiece stores running, swimming, and cycling stats all on your wrist, while also tracking heart rate.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - RoboCop: Breaking Down the Special Effects of the RoboCop Suit
video:video.video:description: For the latest reboot of sci-fi classic RoboCop, filmmakers opted for a mix of visual effects to achieve a realistic look. Fxguide’s Mike Seymour dives into the combination of creating a special effects suit for star Joel Kinnaman to wear, and the post CGI work that helped bring the half-man/half-robot to life.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Mr. Peabody & Sherman and Today’s Remakes of Classic Cartoons
video:video.video:description: Pertinent question about the Mr. Peabody and Sherman cartoon: Why? It's a half-century-old cartoon with no brand recognition. But more to the point, all these expensive reboots tend to take away the things that made the original kids' shows…weird.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Preparation & Recovery for Catastrophes
video:video.video:description: Can you reduce an earthquake’s impact before it strikes? In this World Economic Forum discussion, Japan’s director of land and real property market, Satoru Nishikawa, explains how better planning for natural disasters can help us manage catastrophic risk, enabling quicker recovery times.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug: Creating a Waterlogged Action Sequence
video:video.video:description: Director Peter Jackson and FXguide’s Mike Seymour reveal how a pivotal seven-minute action sequence in The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug was created with a combined 98 hours of footage from aerial shots, green-screen sets, live-action shoots, and complex CG environments.

video:video.video:title: Inside Innovation - Brass Monkey: Reinventing Multiscreen Gaming Experiences [Sponsored Content]
video:video.video:description:
Infrared5 co-founders Chris and Rebecca Allen are revolutionizing the multi-screen experience. With their popular computer game Brass Monkey they’re bringing people together with socially, multi-screen experiences that turn smart phones into game controllers and PC/Tablets into consoles.
Brought to you by Intel.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - How to Improve the Academy Awards
video:video.video:description: It’s excruciatingly dull and doesn’t even feature the most important awards on the telecast—highlighting best actor over best scientific and technical achievement? The nerve! Angry Nerd offers advice on how to improve this year’s Oscar awards ceremony.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at the Aerobie AeroPress Coffee-maker
video:video.video:description: It’s small in size, but packs the strong, flavorful punch that comes from a French press, with the clean and simple design of a drip coffee.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Using Smart Phones to Farm Better
video:video.video:description: Temperature, carbon output, water usage—that's all data that a farmer could use to get better crops. And it's also available, via satellite, to the average smart phone. In this World Economic Forum discussion, Wim Bastiaanssen, a water resource engineer at Delft University, argues that this tech could someday feed the world.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Late Night with Seth Meyers and Stale After-Hours Talk Shows
video:video.video:description: Seth Meyers is ready to take over the Late Night throne, but with an antiquated show formula riddled with predictable monologues, commercials, celebrity interviews, commercials, skits—and did we mention more commercials?—how can the former S.N.L. star break out from the rest of the late night pack? Angry Nerd offers a simple solution.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at the Philips Hue Connected Light Bulbs
video:video.video:description: The Philips Hue Connected Light Bulbs lets you set the mood—or not—with a digital app to control the color and brightness of the bulbs with just a few swipes.

video:video.video:title: Inside Innovation - Floored: Reimagining 3D Experiences for the Real World [Sponsored Content]
video:video.video:description: David Eisenberg, co-founder and CEO of Floored, explains how his company transforms real estate floor plans into 3D experiences using Intel's agile technology, allowing consumers to skip the walkthrough and take a virtual 3D tour instead. Brought to you by Intel.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - The New Frontier of Medical Robots
video:video.video:description: In this World Economic Forum discussion, Carnegie Mellon roboticist Howard Choset shows how snake-like robots can perform minimally invasive surgeries, decreasing cost and patient recovery time.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Questlove on Banding Together with Common, Erykah Badu, D'Angelo, & Q-Tip: Love Music Again
video:video.video:description:
Check out WIRED's music issue featuring Ahmir 'Questlove' Thompson at: http://www.wired.com/listen
Music: THEESatisfaction "Existinct"

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Questlove on Record Shopping & Musical Bonding with His Dad: Love Music Again
video:video.video:description:
Check out WIRED's music issue featuring Ahmir 'Questlove' Thompson at: http://www.wired.com/listen
Music: "Big Headed" Performed by Kooley High Written DJ Prince, Charlie Smarts, Tab-One

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Questlove on Prince's 1999 & Hiding Albums from His Mom: Love Music Again
video:video.video:description:
Check out WIRED's music issue featuring Ahmir 'Questlove' Thompson at: http://www.wired.com/listen
Music: "Ya Times Up" Performed by Kooley High Written Foolery, Charlie Smarts, Tab-One, Rapsody, DJ Ill Digitz

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Questlove on J Dilla, Vinyl Snobs & Lo-fi Hip-hop: Love Music Again
video:video.video:description:
Check out WIRED's music issue featuring Ahmir 'Questlove' Thompson at: http://www.wired.com/listen
Music: "Unfound" Performed by Kooley High Written Napoleon Wright II, Charlie Smarts, Tab-One, Homeboy Sandman

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Questlove on Technology Killing (and Creating) the DJ Star: Love Music Again
video:video.video:description:
Check out WIRED's music issue featuring Ahmir 'Questlove' Thompson at: http://www.wired.com/listen
Music: "Days Passed Me By" Performed by Kooley High Written Napoleon Wright II, Charlie Smarts, Tab-One

video:video.video:title: Love Music Again: The WIRED Music Issue featuring Ahmir 'Questlove' Thompson
video:video.video:description: Digital Edition on sale 2.18.14 On Newsstands 2.25.14

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - The Unnecessary RoboCop Remake
video:video.video:description: They’ve resurrected RoboCop and we can’t figure out why. Actor Joel Kinnaman has a big helmet to fill, and considering all of the outrageous changes that have been made to the reboot, Angry Nerd is doubtful that the new cyborg will live up to the task.

video:video.video:title: Inside Innovation - Makey Makey: Making a Better World…One Carrot Keyboard at a Time [Sponsored Content]
video:video.video:description:
Jay Silver and his co-founder's concept was simple: Hook up everyday objects to small circuits and turn them into touchpads. See how their MaKey MaKey invention kit is changing the way we interact with the world.
Brought to you by Intel.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at the Logitech UE Boom
video:video.video:description: Logitech’s UE Boom combines Bluetooth streaming with a circular design that offers 360-degree sound.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Global Sustainability & Planetary Boundaries
video:video.video:description: In this World Economic Forum discussion, Johan Rockström, executive director of the Stockholm Resilience Centre, proposes a new scientific framework called Planetary Boundaries—a way of thinking about consumption and sustainability that could help keep Earth habitable.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - The Most Famous Female Comic Book Character is a Franchise Flop
video:video.video:description: A kick-ass lady protagonist? Check. Greek mythology? Check. Comic book source material? Check. Wonder Woman has all the ingredients for a hit TV series. So…where is it?

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at the Cocktail Kingdom Ice Ball Maker
video:video.video:description: With its heavy anodized aluminum mold, Cocktail Kingdom’s Ice Ball Maker transforms cubes into spheres for ice that lasts longer than your typical bricks from a tray.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Online Education: Expanding and Personalizing Access
video:video.video:description: Is the education system ready for a revolution? In this World Economic Forum discussion Jose Ferreira, CEO and founder of Knewton, explains how a more personalized, adaptive program would increase access to education and improve the quality of teaching.

video:video.video:title: Inside Innovation - Born of Sound: Transforming Sound into Art [Sponsored Content]
video:video.video:description:
Consider it sound you can see. Find out how Ashik and Jenelle Mohan of Born of Sound are using audio recordings to create works of art, bringing to life a child’s laugh or heartbeat in a fluid, vibrant print.
Brought to you by Intel.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Will Disney Ruin Star Wars?
video:video.video:description: With Disney’s acquisition of Lucasfilm, the House of Mouse and J.J. Abrams are well on their way to destroying all that’s right with Star Wars…or are they? Angry Nerd poses an alternate ending to the Walt and George partnership.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at the Trusco Toolbox
video:video.video:description: This steel toolbox from Japanese brand Trusco adds a double-hinged lid and some slick design to the classic form.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Engineering Sustainable Biofuels
video:video.video:description: How do you feed the world, make biofuel, and remain sustainable? In this World Economic Forum discussion, MIT chemical engineer Kristala Prather says that microbes might provide an answer.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - The Big Bang Theory’s Shortcomings and Inaccurate Portrayal of Geek Culture
video:video.video:description: You'd think the Angry Nerd would be square in the targeting sights of The Big Bang Theory. You'd think he'd love the show. And yet…and yet….

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at the littleBits Deluxe Kit
video:video.video:description: Consider it electronic Lego. littleBits consists of tiny modules that snap together to form circuits, creating simple devices and teaching basic electronics.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Milk Refrigeration Systems for India's Off-Grid Communities
video:video.video:description: As the largest producer and consumer of milk in the world, India faces a serious problem when it comes to off-grid dairy farmers. In this World Economic Forum discussion, Promethean Power Systems co-founder Sam White describes his approach to ensuring that milk is properly refrigerated and not spoiled by bacteria.

video:video.video:title: WIRED February 2014: How the US Almost Killed the Internet
video:video.video:description: Google, Facebook, Microsoft, and other tech titans have had to fight for their lives—against their own government. This month, we take a look inside their year from hell, and why the web will never be the same. Also, see what happens when gene-modifying masters Monsanto try to take nature's path, how one man hacked OKCupid to find the girl of his dreams, and the city-within-a-city Zappos CEO Tony Hsieh is building in Las Vegas. Plus: the Data Miner's Guide to Romance, Rick Rubin, and more!

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Hierarchical Design
video:video.video:description: Strong and stiff and materials comprised of mostly air are well on their way to commercialization. In this World Economic Forum Discussion, Caltech materials scientist Julia Greer talks about their use in "hierarchal design," and the impact it will have on increased efficiency and the prominence of solar cells.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Walking With Dinosaurs: Muscle Simulation and Feathered Effects Exclusive
video:video.video:description: Find out how animation company Animal Logic used complex feather and muscle simulation systems to depict the prehistoric animals in Walking With Dinosaurs.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Safety and the Self-Driving Car
video:video.video:description: Udacity CEO and co-founder Sebastian Thrun explains why self-driving cars are the future and Holy Grail for road safety. In this World Economic Forum discussion, the engineer and innovator describes how the auto-cruising vehicles will transform society and save lives.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Riddick and Hollywood's Failed Attempts at Using POV Cameras
video:video.video:description: Seeing carnage through a character’s eyes used to mean something. Nowadays, Hollywood is wasting POV shots in sci-fi films like Vin Diesel’s Riddick. Angry Nerd explains why these fancy-schmancy first-person perspectives are failing, and he issues the Tinseltown execs an ultimatum.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at the Snowpeak Hozuki Lantern
video:video.video:description: The Hozuki lantern from Snow Peak goes for versatility around the campsite—both inside and outside the tent.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at Amazon's Kindle Paperwhite
video:video.video:description: Amazon’s turned a new page with its latest Paperwhite e-reader. See what’s been upgraded and what’s been ditched in favor of the new model.

video:video.video:title: The Window - Flying Christmas Trees: Helicopters Bring Them From the Farm to Front and Center
video:video.video:description: It’s an outdoor version of the claw game, but with fast, low flying helicopters as the claw and Christmas trees as the prize. At the Hunter Family Farm in Olympia, Wash., helicopter pilots fly across nearly 400 acres, picking up bundles of trees and transporting them, so they can be processed and loaded for your holiday pleasure.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Chris Baker’s Favorite Christmas Movie of All Time
video:video.video:description: A quest for films that genuinely reflect the spirit of the holidays leads the Angry Nerd to create an all-new celebration in honor of the best Christmas movie-maker of all time: Shane Black.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - A Look at the Belkin Conserve Insight Energy Monitor
video:video.video:description: Belkin’s Conserve Insight energy monitor tells you how much juice—and dough—your appliances are using so you can decide what’s worth plugging in.

video:video.video:title: WIRED January 2014 Issue: Wearing the Future
video:video.video:description: Soon, the sharpest-dressed people will be wearing computers. Wearable technology will surpass fitness trackers and Google Glass to become as important as the smartphone, the primary interface through which we experience the world. For the January issue, industrial design firm Branch envisioned the classy wearable of the future for our cover, and senior editor Bill Wasik's feature laid out a roadmap for how we'll get there.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug and the Evolution of CG Dragons
video:video.video:description: For years, it’s been a fantasy cinema rule that real actors and CG dragons just don’t mix—ever. With the new release of The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug, will Peter Jackson be able to avoid the pitfalls of the disastrous dragons featured in flicks like Dragonheart, Reign of Fire, and Eragon?

video:video.video:title: Happy Holidays from Codefellas
video:video.video:description: Agent Topple attempts to get some holiday spirit.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Chris Baker Responds to YouTubers About Kick-Ass 2 and the Real-Life Superheroes Trend
video:video.video:description: The Angry Nerd has read your comments about his loathing of Kick-Ass 2 and the trend of real-life people who become cosplay vigilantes. You have failed to convince him to change his position on the subject.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Can Ben Affleck Successfully Suit Up as the Dark Knight?
video:video.video:description: Has everyone finished panicking about Ben Affleck being cast as the Dark Knight in Batman vs. Superman? Because the Angry Nerd thinks you should chill—Affleck could totally pull this off. (Just think of Daredevil as a…starter superhero movie.)

video:video.video:title: MIT Surveillance Video of Aaron Swartz, January 2011
video:video.video:description: MIT Surveillance Video of Aaron Swartz, January 2011

video:video.video:title: The Window - Crescent Dunes Solar Energy Project Part 2: Building the Power Plant
video:video.video:description: Outside Tonopah, Nev., a construction team of 600 is working to get the Crescent Dunes Solar Energy project up and running by 2014. WIRED has an exclusive look inside the construction of this first-of-its-kind renewable-energy power plant.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Giving Thanks for TV Shows That End Before Their Time
video:video.video:description: It’s the time of the year for counting blessings and giving thanks. And the Angry Nerd is most thankful for the cancellation of Futurama—because it let the show go out on a high note (and avoid a slow decline, like so many other one-time favorites).

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Thor The Dark World: Previsualization Effects Exclusive
video:video.video:description: To create the world of Asgard in Thor: The Dark World, filmmaker Alan Taylor enlisted the help of digital effects company The Third Floor. Using a process called previsualization, The Third Floor created fully rendered low-res CG sets and characters, allowing the director to see, plan out, and experiment with scenes before shooting them.

video:video.video:title: The Window - Crescent Dunes Solar Energy Project Part 1: The Facility
video:video.video:description: Take a look inside the first commercial-scale solar energy plant to use nothing more than the sun, molten salt, and a whole lot of mirrors to send power to the people. If the Crescent Dunes Solar Energy facility works as promised, it could be a model for the future of renewable energy.

video:video.video:title: What's Inside - Teeth Whitening Strips
video:video.video:description: They’re tiny, sticky pieces that pack a big punch. From hydrogen peroxide to sodium hydroxide, find out which ingredients make up teeth whitening strips, and how they work together to transform coffee- and tartar-stained teeth into pearly whites.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - The Watered-Down Hunger Games Trilogy
video:video.video:description: People say The Hunger Games is a watered-down Young Adult version of the brilliant Japanese movie Battle Royale, but Angry Nerd completely disagrees. He likens the sci-fi tale to a watered-down version of Running Man, but with a premise that doesn’t actually work.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Matt Smith Says Farewell to the Cast of Doctor Who
video:video.video:description: After four years as the Doctor, Matt Smith is saying farewell to his time-traveling role on the hit BBC show. Now Smith, along with co-star Jenna Coleman and writer-producer Steven Moffat, debriefs about his time on the show, his departure, and what's next.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Aubrey Plaza, Maggie Carey, and Alia Shawkat Share Their “To Do List”
video:video.video:description: Parks and Recreation’s Aubrey Plaza sits down with the To Do List’s writer-director Maggie Carey, and co-star Alia Shawkat to talk about starring in the coming-of-age comedy, and how she used the director’s high school diaries for inspiration in her role.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Community’s Dan Harmon Talks About his Adult Swim Show Rick and Morty
video:video.video:description: Community’s Dan Harmon teamed up with voice actor and writer Justin Roiland to create the new animated comedy Rick and Morty. The two sit down to talk about their Adult Swim show, which focuses on the crazy adventures of a sociopathic, ingenious scientist and his less-than-genius grandson.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - The Unraveling of Secret Societies in Pop Cultural References
video:video.video:description: Long gone are the days when secret societies were, in fact, secret. Now, hacks use underground organizations as shorthand for evil in their pop culture products and Angry Nerd demands an end to it. Is a mention of the Templars in Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag and Jay Z rapping about the Illuminati worth taking away from the power of the actual conspiracy theories?

video:video.video:title: Television Remote Control (Tuner) (ca. 1961)
video:video.video:description: Early technology to enable the channel-surfer.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Bill Gates & President Bill Clinton: Looking Forward and Maintaining Optimism-Exclusive Interview
video:video.video:description: Passion and optimism often go hand-in-hand, which couldn’t be truer for Bill Gates and President Bill Clinton when it comes to their outlook on the future. The two share their thoughts on the rapid pace and excitement of today’s innovations, and how humanity’s balance between conflict and cooperation will continue to fuel economic opportunity for years to come. For more from Bill Gates and President Clinton, check out the December 2013 issue of WIRED.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Bill Gates & President Bill Clinton: Changing the World Through Philanthropy-Exclusive Interview
video:video.video:description:
Bill Gates and President Bill Clinton have managed to transition from Microsoft co-founder and former U.S. commander-in-chief to hands-on philanthropists. With a passion for charity and aid work, the two describe their health- and education-focused initiatives, and explain why their statuses don’t mean squat when they’re helping out in developing nations.
For more from Bill Gates and President Clinton, check out the December 2013 issue of WIRED.

video:video.video:title: December 2013 Issue: Guest Editor Bill Gates Wants You to Fix the World
video:video.video:description: How do we end poverty? Design for the developing world? Eradicate polio? Those are the kind of questions that Bill Gates, guest editor of WIRED's December issue, wants to answer. We're looking at how technology and science can invent a better world—with an interview with Bill Gates and President Bill Clinton, a guiltless gift guide, prototypes of planet-saving gadgets, and a few glow-in-the-dark mosquitos. Online and on Tablets: 11.12.13 On Newsstands: 11.19.13

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Bill Gates & President Bill Clinton: The Global Economy and the End of American Exceptionalism-Exclusive Interview
video:video.video:description:
With American exceptionalism waning, is the U.S. destined to be left in the dust? Bill Gates and President Bill Clinton talk about the significance of building a future of shared success and responsibility in order to create a thriving global economy.
For more from Bill Gates and President Clinton, check out the December 2013 issue of WIRED.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Bill Gates & President Bill Clinton: Technology and the Value of Connectivity-Exclusive Interview
video:video.video:description: From medical vaccines to financial services to educational resources, connectivity is key. Bill Gates and President Bill Clinton explain the positive impact of being plugged in on a global scale. For more from Bill Gates and President Clinton, check out the December 2013 issue of WIRED.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - PlayStation 4: Mark Cerny Breaks Down the Hardware
video:video.video:description: Sony’s PlayStation 4 console could re-define the gaming industry. Lead system architect Mark Cerny and Sony Computer Entertainment execs Andrew House and Shuhei Yoshida explain how—with footage (including an exclusive) from the new games designed to take advantage of the new system.

video:video.video:title: Gadget Lab - PlayStation 4: Unboxing the New Game Console
video:video.video:description: We got the PlayStation 4! Sony’s new console comes out on November 15 in the US, but we went to Sony’s Tokyo HQ and asked engineering director Yasuhiro Ootori to give WIRED an exclusive look inside the new system—literally. Like, he takes it apart piece by piece and explains what all the parts do, and how they fit together.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - The Implausibility of Thor's Physics-Defying Hammer, Mjölnir
video:video.video:description: Thor’s hammer Mjölnir is undoubtedly one of the most badass superhero weapons around. But its physics-defying and trajectory-changing travel powers are too much for Angry Nerd to handle. A majestic hammer...come on!

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Ender's Game: Creating a Zero-G Battle Room Effects Exclusive
video:video.video:description: A signature sequence in Gavin Hood’s newest film Ender’s Game is the zero-G battle room, a place where the titular character played by Asa Butterfield trains in space. Hoping to create a sense of weightlessness, the filmmakers shot actors in a mix of harnesses and on wires against a greenscreen set.

video:video.video:title: Mr. Know-It-All - Wearing a Dust Mask in a Foreign Country
video:video.video:description: Health-conscious folks wondering if it’s politically correct to don a dust mask while in Beijing needn’t worry about causing a cultural offense. Mr. Know-It-All gives the dirt on how to avoid the dirt—and pollution—when in a foreign country.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - The Inauthenticity of CG Blood and the Demise of Karo Syrup and Red Food Coloring
video:video.video:description: Angry Nerd used to love binge-watching scary movies on Halloween. But when directors started swapping classic fake blood for CG gore, the authenticity of it all went out the window. What happened to the squibs of Karo syrup and red food coloring that could splatter, squirt, and spray with frightening realism?

video:video.video:title: Maniac Pumpkin Carvers
video:video.video:description: We foresee that you'll get in the Halloween spirit with Maniac Pumpkin Carvers as they show off their skills with a Gadget Lab-chosen knife and an intricate Star Wars jack-o’-lantern.

video:video.video:title: Game|Life - Atari by Design and More Highlights from the Lab at the National Museum of Play
video:video.video:description: At the National Museum of Play, Chris Kohler visits an exhibit all about classic video game maker Atari, and he gets hands-on inside the museum’s lab of rare games.

video:video.video:title: Mr. Know-It-All - Un-Friending Friends on Facebook
video:video.video:description: Social media has redefined 'friend' to include estranged classmates and distant acquaintances. Mr. Know-It-All explains why it’s OK to quit second-rate pals on Facebook without fear of feeling guilty.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Deconstructing LEGO: How a Beloved Toy Sold Out to Cross-Brand Licensing
video:video.video:description: LEGO has strayed from its original purpose, and the Angry Nerd will not stand for it. The creative potential of infinitely interlockable plastic pieces has been killed by tie-ins with kiddie titles like Batman and Harry Potter. It used to be about the bricks, man!

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Lili Taylor on The Conjuring
video:video.video:description: Actress Lili Taylor talks about starring in the horror flick The Conjuring and how she learned to nail a bloodcurdling scream.

video:video.video:title: Game|Life - Inside the Library at the National Museum of Play
video:video.video:description: The library at the National Museum of Play in Rochester, N.Y., boasts a rare collection of strategy guides, designs, and background materials from old-school video games. Chris Kohler takes a look at the original documents from classic games, including Wizard and the Princess, Mystery House, and King’s Quest II.

video:video.video:title: Soaring Over Mars
video:video.video:description: The Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter has seen many places on the planet. One of the most interesting is one of the great canyon systems on Mars.

video:video.video:title: Mr. Know-It-All - Serving Genetically Modified Food at Dinner Parties
video:video.video:description: When hosting a party where genetically modified foods are what’s for dinner, is it proper etiquette to warn your GMO-averse friends ahead of time? Mr. Know-It-All offers sage advice on how to handle.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - TV Networks Are Running Out of Original Ideas
video:video.video:description: Hunky time-traveling Ichabod Crane has made Chris Baker lose his head. Why is every other TV show an updated version of some classic fairytale or children's story?

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Slash Talks Movie Music and Scoring the Horror Film Nothing Left to Fear
video:video.video:description: Velvet Revolver and former Guns N’ Roses guitarist, Slash, sits down to talk about scoring Anthony Leonardi III’s new horror flick, Nothing Left to Fear.

video:video.video:title: November 2013 Issue: The Next Steve Jobs
video:video.video:description:
Genius is everywhere - but we're wasting it. In the November issue of WIRED, we explore how to unleash the great minds of tomorrow. Plus 26 winter gear essentials, the Nest Protect, North Korean Instagrams, and much more!
Online and on Tablets: 10.15.2013 On Newsstands: 10.22.2013

video:video.video:title: Game|Life - Rare Arcade Games at the National Museum of Play
video:video.video:description: Chris Kohler gets hands on at the National Museum of Play in Rochester, N.Y., by testing out working models of rare arcade games, including a Hercules pinball machine, ActRaiser, and Nintendo Super System.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - What the Bleep is Bumblebee? Indecisive Autobot Keeps Switching his Vehicular Form
video:video.video:description: The Transformer known as Bumblebee keeps changing his alternative automobile form, and Chris Baker is issuing a moving violation. Is the Autobot a VW Bug? Or a mustang? A station wagon? A Zamboni?! Stop the madness!

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Zombie Apocalypse Survival Tactics from The Walking Dead's Norman Reedus
video:video.video:description: He might play a zombie slayer on-screen, but Norman Reedus swears he’d be toast during a real apocalypse. The Walking Dead star tells WIRED about his lack of survival instincts and why he’d rely on an Uber as his getaway car.

video:video.video:title: Game|Life - Inside the National Museum of Play's Rare Game Collection
video:video.video:description: The National Museum of Play in Rochester, N.Y. recently acquired one of the largest collections of Japanese and European video games. From Mother to Zool to Doshin the Giant, Game|Life editor Chris Kohler gets the first look at the incredible rarities.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Why is WWE on SyFy?! Cable Networks Straying from Their Original Missions
video:video.video:description: Cable networks are straying from their original mission, and Chris Baker isn't having it. Why is wrestling on the SyFy channel? Why is Star Trek playing on BBC America? When's the last time you saw a classic American movie on AMC?

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Eric Andre and Hannibal Buress Talk New Season on Adult Swim
video:video.video:description: Senior Editor Peter Rubin sits down with the eclectic Eric Andre, Hannibal Buress, and Derrick Beckles—star of Adult Swim’s upcoming spoof celebrity news show, Hot Package—to talk about the new season of The Eric Andre Show, and the weirdest thing they’ve seen on the oddball network.

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Alfonso and Jonás Cuarón on “Gravity”
video:video.video:description: Like father, like son. Alfonso Cuarón talks about working with son Jonás on Gravity, his new film starring Sandra Bullock and George Clooney. The Y Tu Mamá También and Children of Men director also explains how he achieved the realistic CGI of outer space with the help of some robots and brand-new technology.

video:video.video:title: Santa Fe - The Happening - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Miss the Santa Fe stop of Station to Station? Don't fret, we have a recap of all great performances and art installations from the event. Art by Urs Fischer, Ernesto Neto, Liz Glynn, and Kenneth Anger; and performances by Eleanor Friedberger, Cat Power, THEESatisfaction, Nite Jewel, The Handsome Family, and much more.

video:video.video:title: Codefellas - The Cougar Lies with Spanish Moss
video:video.video:description: Agent Topple's mustache does its dirty work, and Nicole brokers a deal for peace. But why is the NSA collecting millions of Instagram brunch photos? And if your waffles have nothing to hide, what are they so worried about?

video:video.video:title: LA - Ariel Pink - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: In conversation with Doug Aitken, artist Ariel Pink talks about the layers of his work, and how he uses media to collect his processes.

video:video.video:title: The Prelinger Library - San Francisco - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: The Prelinger Library is a gem. Founded in 2004 and operated by Rick Prelinger and Megan Shaw Prelinger, the library houses over 50,000 books, periodicals and pieces of print ephemera, the collection specializes in materials and works not typically found in public libraries. The public library is privately funded in San Francisco.

video:video.video:title: San Francisco Bay Area - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Get ready for the Bay! Take a sneak peek of the artists showcased in the last leg of the Station to Station series.

video:video.video:title: Momentum - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Anticipation is growing for the Santa Fe stop of Station to Station.

video:video.video:title: Mojave Desert - Victor - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Artist, Victor talks about the founding of his church and the history of the lands.

video:video.video:title: Los Angeles - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Welcome to LA. Catch a glimpse of what's to come for the Los Angeles stop of Station to Station.

video:video.video:title: The Happening - Pittsburgh - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Watch highlights of the Pittsburgh stop of Station to Station.

video:video.video:title: Flavor Explosion - Shitake Flatbread
video:video.video:description: Amp up the umami at home with this recipe from our friends at Bon Appétit. Alison Roman, in the BA test kitchen, worked with Dan Felder, head of R&D at David Chang's Momofuku Culinary Lab in New York, to develop this recipe for optimum umami pow.

video:video.video:title: Bon Appetit + Momofuku = Flavor Explosion!
video:video.video:description: See how the chefs at the Momofuku Culinary Lab create dishes packed with umami flavor!

video:video.video:title: Tastes Like Chicken - Chicken-Free + Sweet Potato Hash
video:video.video:description:
The combination of the strips, sweet potatoes, and chipotle makes for a hearty and full-flavored dish.
Want the recipe? Check out WIRED for this recipe and more in the October issue!

video:video.video:title: WIRED Live - Key & Peele Talk Game of Thrones and New Season
video:video.video:description: Genius sketch comedians Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele talk to Peter Rubin about their favorite sketches, the new season of their Comedy Central show Key & Peele, and Game of Thrones. Because Game of Thrones.

video:video.video:title: The Happening - Chicago - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Watch highlights of the Chicago stop of Station to Station.

video:video.video:title: The Whip Cracker - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: The menacing lashes belong to 44-year-old Chris Camp, whose jolting appearance at each Station to Station show comes about halfway through the night. At first, as he crouches, Vader-style, on a darkened riser in the center of the crowd, he’s largely hidden from view. But when he rises—accompanied by the droning sound of two floor-wandering auctioneers—Camp is impossible to miss.

video:video.video:title: October 2013 Issue: The Joy of Cooking with Science!
video:video.video:description:
Curious what it took to create the Doritos Locos Taco? Need Recipes for a vegan 'meat' feast? We've got the answers to that and more in the October 2013 issue of WIRED. Analyze the fifth taste, explore the world of bug sushi; chefs and researchers are engineering the cuisine of tomorrow. Also in this issue: Beyond - Two Souls, Cuarón, and a special tablet video with Bon Appétit!
Online and on Tablets: 9.17.2013 On Newstands: 9.24.2013

video:video.video:title: St. Paul - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: What is making art flourish in St. Paul and Minneapolis? Watch and find out.

video:video.video:title: Train Tracks to Sound Tracks - Giorgio Moroder - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: How can you translate the memory of a train ride into a song? Giorgio Moroder intends to do just that.

video:video.video:title: Pittsburgh - Nomadic Sculptures - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Outside of the musical and art performances were interactive art installations. Calling them 'Nomadic Sculptures', artists transformed Yurts into mini art galleries - each giving participators a different atmospheric experience.

video:video.video:title: Calexico - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Members of the band Calexico play an acoustic version of Crystal Frontier in Frank Lloyd Wright’s Taliesin West.

video:video.video:title: Detritus - Jack Pierson - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Jack Pierson sits down with Doug Aitken and discusses what his art evokes.

video:video.video:title: Free Network Foundation - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Free Network Foundation is doing something radical; helping communities build their own computer networks. The freedom of communication is a key motivator for the team at Free Network Foundation

video:video.video:title: Liz Glynn - Relativity - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Liz Glynn takes us through her installation, a “model of the universe,” that adds layers of information at every stop of the train. The installation changes and expands, moving from the Big Bang theory to Hubble’s expanding universe, and beyond. The dimly lit structure includes a maze of felt walls, with chalk drawings accumulating over the course of the performative lectures given by the artist.

video:video.video:title: James Turrell on Moving Towards a New Landscape - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: James Turrell, in Conversation with Doug Aitken, discusses Roden Crater and his ideology on the horizontal landscape.

video:video.video:title: Pittsburgh - Artist Trio and The Kansas City Marching Cobras - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: YOSHIMIO, Sawyer, and Bharoocha gathered in the lobby of Pittsburgh's Union Station for a gorgeous impromptu drum show, which then segued into an energetic outdoor turn by the Kansas City Marching Cobras. Dancers flipped, shook, and pulled onlookers from the crowd along with them — drums rocketing into the night sky.

video:video.video:title: Codefellas - Shout to All My Lost Spies
video:video.video:description: Topple’s bravado is put to the test when his old-school spy game gets the green light. Winters busts out her best pep talk, but can Topple get back to his fighting weight? The fate of the world rests on the shoulders of one man—and his mustache.

video:video.video:title: Fragments - Taylor-Ruth Baldwin - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Taylor-Ruth Baldwin gives us a glimpse of why she creates her art.

video:video.video:title: Minneapolis - Perceived Boundaries with Kate Casanova - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Kate Casanova discusses what drives the concept of her art, and how it blurs the lines of humans and nature.

video:video.video:title: Chicago - The Community of Chicago - Damon Locks - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Damon Locks of the band Trenchmouth talks about his love of the city Chicago and the way it adds layers to his works of art.

video:video.video:title: Chicago - A Collage of Culture - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: "It's kind of an island; it's own cultural island." In this Chicago minute, we explore the third largest city in the country and it's impact on the arts.

video:video.video:title: The Garment District - Sound Patterns of Pittsburgh - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Multi-instrumentalist Jennifer Baron talks about her new project, The Garment District (http://thegarmentdistrictmusic.com/), while in Pittsburgh with Station to Station. She discusses creating at the intersection between pop and experimental music, and how she uses the patterns in nature and urban landscapes to influence the patterns in her songs.

video:video.video:title: Station to Station - New York - Nomadic Happenings: Artist Trio and Jonah Bokaer
video:video.video:description: Yoshimio, Hisham Akira Bharoocha, and Ryan Saywer join forces for a music mashup; later, we get a sneak peek of the dance medley from Jonah Boakaer and AIRLOCKS for the New York stop of Station to Station.

video:video.video:title: Design FX - Game of Thrones: Dragon Effects Exclusive
video:video.video:description: Daenerys Targaryen's dragons on HBO's Games of Thrones are fan favorites, and WIRED has an incredible, exclusive look at how they were brought to life with feature film quality by the visual effects artists at Pixmondo. Virtual wind tunnels, water simulations and real world references all played a part in constructing their realistic behaviors.

video:video.video:title: The Noble Writer - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: In this artist profile from Station to Station, Gary Indiana, an American contemporary writer, artist, and filmmaker, discusses the state of writing in a modern, visual culture, and how modern technology influences the creative process.

video:video.video:title: The Lure of the Journey - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: As Station to Station makes its way across 3000 miles of the United States, we're reminded of the joy and adventure of the classic road trip - truck stops, strange foods, unexpected discoveries just around the bend. It's a forward drive into the unknown; it's an event that makes us aware of our surroundings in a way that can't be achieved from the office. And a part of it is, as explained in the video above, fueled by "this notion we we're always gonna move West."

video:video.video:title: Mr. Know-It-All - Automated Parallel Parking
video:video.video:description: Is it OK to embrace automated parallel parking? Or does it make you look like a helpless schmuck? Mr. Know-It-All helps you take control back from your Lexus.

video:video.video:title: It Begins in New York - Station to Station
video:video.video:description: Station to Station launches in New York, arguably the best place to start a 3-week-long tour of the United States. One of the most heavily populated urban cities in the world, it's a hotbed for arts, culture, creativity, and technology. Featuring performers like Ariel Pink's Haunted Graffiti and Suicide, and artists like Olaf Breuning and Liz Glynn.

video:video.video:title: Angry Nerd - Bad Ideas from Hollywood: Punctuation in Titles—Age of the Colon
